It's a fairly fun and semi-hardcore retro pixel indie platformer with a lot of expansion content.

Gameplay consists of platforming gauntlets with checkpoints that can optionally be destroyed for extra gems, followed by a boss encounter.

The biggest draw of Shovel Knight is the excellent production value that went into the crisp pixel graphics and chiptune music.

150134124.review:
Shovel Knight sounds great, nails down the visuals perfectly, has fun simple systems, even if controls are a bit unresponsive when compared to modern side scrollers. The first 2 hours are fun and moderately challanging. However, the ending missions of the base game crank up the challanges, where the systems' simplicity is overcompensated too much for my personal liking, with actively obstructing the Player vision, randomized hazards and mechanics that are not and never were fun (eg. ice sliding). I couldn't neither get irritated or push myself to redo the same parts for multiple times in a row until I'd get that right, and I churned.
The game onboards the Player very well, and has great flow until that part. I'd recommend it on sale, since there's much to be liked about it and fundamentally it's a good game.

149956237.review:
Imagine taking Kickstarter stretch goals so seriously that your modest homage to NES classics turns into a sprawling collection of 4 campaigns and 1 fighting game on the side. In terms of basic building blocks (art, music, setting, level design, gameplay mechanics), Treasure Trove is competent but unexceptional, and feels inferior to its original references like Mega Man or DuckTales. However, what it lacks in pure inspiration, it makes up for in diligence, always giving more varied stuff to do and more well-balanced challenges to beat until you can’t help but be charmed by its dedication and scope.

Playing the 4 campaigns in the default order, I found them steadily getting better and better. Shovel Knight’s beginning is rather unfriendly, with inertive, cumbersome movement and the ever-frustrating "get hit midair and fall into a pit due to knockback" shtick. There’s also a Souls-like money-losing system that looks out of place in a platformer with frequent instadeath hazards. One could chalk it all up to retro design, but this is an unsatisfying kind of challenge; the kind where the main hurdle is game mechanics themselves rather than enemies or spikes. However, once you buy some QoL upgrades (as well as just get accustomed to the controls), most of the above stops being an issue, and the difficulty becomes nicely balanced until the end.

Plague Knight progresses in a similar way, with a moveset that’s very unruly and guarantees you a rough start, but also quite unique and rewarding once you get the hang of it. The narrative from here on continues to focus on the same cast, which I found to be a smart decision, since meeting the same knights under different circumstances helps to shape them into proper characters rather than just Mega Man-style bosses.

The biggest improvement comes with Specter Knight, as his moves are radically more fluid, tight and convenient, making level traversal a total joy from the start. You also get a more involved, serious story, as well as a very distinctive hub area. On the flip side, the gameplay gets maybe a tad too easy at times, but that’s okay, since by this point it’s clear that the devs never intended to push the players’ limits too much in the first place. Even for the toughest achievements like deathless or speedruns, the game is never outright punishing, and it would rather give you 10 moderately difficult challenges than 5 really hard ones (which sound totally swell in my book).

Finally, King Knight seals the deal with the biggest, most lush campaign full of adventurous spirit and funny character interactions. His controls are also tight and accessible, if less cool-looking than Specter’s, but the real star is not even platforming or combat anymore; it’s a card game, of all things. An in-universe collectible card game called Joustus deserves special praise both for its seamless integration into the story and for being a wonderfully designed minigame, having just enough strategy to keep it casual yet highly engaging.

As for the oft-criticized fighter/brawler Showdown, it is indeed quite rough around the edges, with most of the difficulty coming from the chaos of randomly chosen conditions. Thankfully, it’s also very cheesable, as every character gets a ranged or safe attack that can be spammed without risking a "proper" engagement. Funny enough, this part also became a trove of extra rare achievements (around 0.3-0.4%, which is equal to or lower than anything in Super Meat Boy, or Dustforce, or Dead Cells, or N++, you name it), even though most are just slightly challenging variations of "do X using Y while Z", probably because the majority of players never bothered to try them.

Overall (and unlike some adjacent indie superstars such as its brother-in-name Hollow Knight), this might not be a game that sets new standards for the genre, but it’s still a lovingly crafted, content-packed experience. All that’s required is a little bit of patience at the start; after that, it stays fresh and varied all the way up to 100% completion. Oh, and be sure to also play some classic Mega Man entries if you haven’t (my personal favorites are 9 and 5), if only to see for yourself the unity between the "new old" and the "old old".

149904993.review:
Shovel Knight is a special game for me.
I was never that much of a video-game person. Never owned a console or had a good PC. My entire gaming experience up to that point was some MMO RPGs and League of Legends (that ran like absolute garbage on my old laptop. 20 FPS max).
So, one day, I watched a review by a upstarting youtuber about this game and it peaked my interest.
I bought it, and spent the whole day playing it like a maniac. I was fascinated.
It was the first actual game I played from beggining to end, and I loved every second of it, even if I though some parts of it were lowkey bs.

For years I waited anxiously for every new campaign, and played again and again. And despite the time, the game never once lost it's magic to me.

I bought this when I was like, 15? Maybe less. And to this day the characters are still charming, the soundtrack is still amazing, the bossess are just as fun. I adore every single part of this game.

11/10
Everyone should play this.

148407913.review:
Shovel Knight? Great game! Everyone knows how great Shovel Knight is. It's a modern game with the DNA of classic NES platformers like "Duck Tales" and "Mega Man." It came out, rocked the world, super fun, sticks with you long after you've beaten it.

And then they made Plague of Shadows, which took the same Shovel Knight levels and let you explore them with Plague Knight's modular explosions. And then they made Specter of Torment, which you could argue is even better than Shovel of Hope, an incredible Ninja Gaiden-esque tragedy telling the tale of the Enchantress' most loyal servant. And just to completely blow our collective minds, they made King of Cards, which gave us a Wario/Donkey Kong-style platformer AND one of those collectible card games that was all the rage back in the day. King of Cards isn't quite as good as Specter of Torment, but it's still quite fun as a cherry on top of the Shovel Knight mythos.

In terms of monetary cost, think of it this way. You're getting two full games (Shovel and Specter), and two expansions (Plague and King) that are as fun as any full game in their own right. So... what, 10, 15 bucks a game? It's a steal.

147773214.review:
Shovel Knight is genuinely one of the greatest games I've played ever, and I heavily recommend it!  There's so much detail and love put into every single aspect of the game, from the story, to the art, to the soundtrack, to the gameplay itself.  All of the characters, secrets, etc, are crafted with such incredible care and it all comes together to form a wonderful product.  If you're a fan of platformers, retro games, or rpgs, I can guarantee you will be more than satisfied with the game.  It's a wonderful love-letter to the NES-SNES era, and takes very obvious cues from games like Megaman and Castlevania, while making its identity wholly its own as well.  The depth of character and continuity of the storyline is incredible and it's very easy to get attached to the characters and world.

It may look like I only recently purchased Shovel Knight, but I actually bought the game from Humble Bundle back in 2017, before Specter of Torment was out, and never redeemed my steam key until recently due to losing access to the email I used to purchase the game, using the Humble direct download.  By the time I thought to redeem it, I had actually lost access to the email I originally used alongside the entire computer that the game was stored on, and I only very recently was able to restore the email account and finally redeem my key and finish the game thanks to the help of a friend who I inexplicably assigned the recovery email to.  Going through Shovel of Hope and Plague of Shadows for the first time in years felt just as incredible as it did when I first played them, and finishing up the rest of Specter of Torment, which I never actually completed back in the day, and being able to play King of Cards for the first time ever were amazing experiences, and it's almost like the developers managed to make each campaign a fuller and better thought-out experience than the last, which is an incredible accomplishment as even Shovel of Hope is an incredibly polished experience.  It genuinely feels like I committed theft by purchasing the game back when it was only ten dollars back in the day, because it is WELL worth the full forty dollars, or fifty if you buy the soundtrack (which is excellent, by the way).

Also, there are actually secret differences between the game depending on which platform you purchase it for.  In the Steam version, as well as the Xbox version, there's a secret fight against the Battletoads from Battletoads, which fits perfectly with the retro aesthetic and inspiration, and in the Playstation versions, in their place, you can face off against Kratos from God of War, and both versions have gear that Shovel Knight can get in the original campaign that go alongside the property of the corresponding version.  The Nintendo versions also have support for the amiibo figures of the characters, which is a fun exclusive for the platform, even if there isn't a special fight.  The game is amazing regardless of the version, but it's worth keeping in mind if you have a preference for the aforementioned characters or features.

The challenge mode and New Game+ give each campaign lots of replayability, and there are tons of collectibles exclusive to each character to keep you coming back if you're a completionist.  As well, there's a co-op mode that allows you and a friend to tackle the campaigns, and a pvp fighting game-esque mode that allows up to four players who can each choose from characters that you don't get to experience gameplay of in the main four campaigns (alongside the four main characters), which even has a story mode to go alongside it.  I haven't gotten to play either of the multiplayer modes yet, but they both seem like lots of fun if you'd like to play the game with a friend or three!

It varies from simple gameplay any casual can pick up on (Specter and King Knight) to mechanically challenging characters that I still lack the skill to play 50 hours later (gosh darn plague knight). 144933441.review:
Great game with charming pixel art and tight gameplay. The game manages to strike a balance between nostalgic aesthetic and modern sensibilities, harkening back to early games without inheriting their limitations.

Shovel Knight is actually a four-in-one deal. In the original campaign, you play as Shovel Knight on a classic adventure fighting enemies and doing tricky platforming using your shovel to bounce around on your enemies heads. The game would be worth it just for this, but there is more:

Plague of Shadows allows you to take control of plague knight, one of Shovel Knight's bosses. While the level layouts are similar to the main campaign, the way you traverse them is totally different. Plague Knight uses explosion alchemical concoctions to send himself flying chaotically around the level. It is difficult to control, but in like a cool fun way. You also are able to customize your bombs with various casings, fuses, and ingredients to create numerous combinations. Really delivers on the promise as playing as Plague Knight.

Specter of Torment of torment puts the player in the shoes of Specter Knight, who wields a scythe which can be used like a skateboard to grind on rails. It's just as rad as it sounds. Additionally, unlike Plague of Shadows which mirrors the original campaign closely, Specter of Torment features a whole set of bespoke levels designed around Specter Knights unique movement.

Finally, King of Cards puts you in control of the pompous King Knight (or Queen Knight, depending on your settings). King of Cards also features original levels and a unique move set. The gimmick on this one though, is the collectable trading card mini-game. The mini-game features a fairly unique system of pushing cards around a grid. While the mini-game likely wouldn't stand on its own, it is certainly fun enough to not overstay its welcome by the end of the story.

If you like platformers or retro games, Shovel Knight is a great pick. I can't wait to see how Yacht Club adapts the classic adventure game in the upcoming Mina the Hollower.

144899753.review: One of the best games I've played in my life with four great stories attached to super fun adventures each with their own unique feel ranging from gameplay mechanics, lively characters/interactions, and accomplishments. 143500251.review: It's just as awesome and frustrating as many classic platformers from the NES and SNES era. If you like those games or have nostalgia for the era, you'll LOVE Shovel Knight. The developers clearly understand what makes those games work well and expounds on it while keeping a lot of the small quirks you'd see from retro platformers themselves attempting to imitate arcade cabinets. The art and character designs are lush and iconic, the music is stellar, and overall the game looks and feels pretty good to play (given the design limitations). My only real complaints is that sometimes the "quirks" of the era err on the more unforgiving side, manifesting as occasional spikes in difficulty, input oddities, and the like. I highly recommend the game to anyone willing to put up with those aspects, and even more so for fans of the genre! 9.0/10.

A good series of Mega Man-like platformers. The movement options are great and the power ups add a bit of versatility, even though I didn't use more than a few. Each game was generally short and the plots were pretty basic. I enjoyed Specter of Torment the most, though Shovel Knight was a close second. The bosses were pretty fun, the stages were varied and had plenty of secrets. There were only about a dozen types of enemies with a few recolors, so that could have been expanded upon. 

My biggest gripes were that the movement aside from combat is kind of slow. It's, as expected, similar in speed to Mega Man. In Specter, there were too many times that I climbed a wall when I didn't intend to, which was annoying. Aside from that, there were very few gameplay issues. 
Recommended to sidescroller fans, just don't expect high speed gameplay.

longer and genuine review:
genuinely one of the best games i have played in a WHILE. the gameplay is very nice and satisfying, with a very nice difficulty to it! there's so much love and care put into emulating all of the best parts of older games, from the larger visuals (with LOVELY spritework and color palettes) to extremely small details like cheatcodes and secrets that you never see in modern games anymore, things put in simply for fun and nothing more

not to mention the *STORY* in all of these games is so wonderful, and it's so so so cool to experience. i love all of the character that everybody has, and it's quite easy to love all of them. the story of each game flows into eachother so naturally, too, that i wouldn't even have realized they were made in reverse order of when they take place if my friend didn't tell me. i also enjoy showdown for the bits of character interactions you wouldn't otherwise get to see! especially because of the place in the timeline it is, it adds a lot and it's quite interesting (even if relatively small!)

on that note, in the age of remote play, i'd definitely recommend giving showdown a chance, because it's extremely fun to sit down and play through with a friend, even if it's a very different game from the other four!

DEFINITELY more than worth the price, 35 USD is a steal for everything that's in this. definitely going to keep me busy for a while! ^_^

I first played this game in 2015, and honestly, it has laid the groundwork for so much of my taste since then... it might get overshadowed nowadays by flashier indie platformers, but it's earned its place in my heart nonetheless.
All of the campaigns are a good time gameplay-wise, echoing the simplicity of older games while being a bit more forgiving, but I think that the most accurate throwback in this game is its return to the old guard's storytelling. Each knight's story is memorable without getting too involved in cutscenes or complex plot points. It doesn't waste your time or go out of its way to make you pay attention to the story, it just... is. Shovel Knight gets praised a lot, but I think that this aspect specifically gets overshadowed.
It's a great retro throwback game, one of the best, and has remained that way.

[/i]

These games aren't perfect by any means. Screens and sections, especially in Shovel of Hope and Plague of Shadows, can be very frustrating. One-hit spikes suck. Relics feel a bit pointless and it's too easy to run out of things to buy. Plague of Shadows being a remix isn't something I entirely agree with and Joustus feels like it would've worked better as a separate game. But I don't care.

The music slaps so hard. The art is fantastic. All 4 of these characters control amazingly and have generally fantastic levels built around them. The story and lore is unexpectedly fantastic and even kind of deep, and can manage comedy as well as sadness. Yacht Club get some major things wrong, but a lot more right and that's really what you notice whilst playing. These games are so good, and the price is such a bargain for 5 whole games. I would very much recommend playing this if you get a chance. Have fun!

142258489.review:
An excellent retro-styled platformer game. However, this game has many versions on different consoles and each console version has exclusive content.

Nintendo 3DS & Wii U (2014):
- You can use items without pausing the game in 3DS and Wii U. 
- 3DS has StreetPass Arena.
- Wii U has Digger's Diary (now defunct due to shutdown of Miiverse).
- Has Amiibo support that unlocks exclusive outfits, challenges and Custom Knight mode where you can customize your character with different skills.

PlayStation 3/4/Vita (2015):
- Has exclusive boss fight that unlocks exclusive gear.

Xbox One (2015):
- Has exclusive boss fight that unlocks exclusive gear (this content is featured in Steam version).

Nintendo Switch (2017)
- Has Amiibo support that unlocks exclusive outfits, challenges (also new co-op ones) and Custom Knight mode where you can customize your character with different skills.

Since the exclusive content is so spread out between different consoles, there is no definitive version of Shovel Knight on Steam and therefore I do not recommend this game.

139704626.review:
[h1]TO HELL WITH THE SWORD, SHOVEL THAT ASS BROTHA[/h1]

Years have passed since this indie darling first wowed the world, and now Shovel Knight has graced almost every platform. In the bundle, you of course have the now classic Shovel Knight, now with the added subtitle “Shovel of Hope”. It combines the pogo attacks from Duck Tales with the level design conventions found in classic Mega Man, all presented with a retro aesthetic. Yet despite the intentionally dated look, there was a lot of love and care that went into making those pixels stand out.

From the Introduction stage, to each of the Order of No Quarter levels, and up until the final confrontation with the Enchantress, Shovel Knight: Shovel of Hope is a fantastically designed platforming experience with bags of character. Every level has a new obstacle to overcome, fully utilising Shovel Knight’s abilities.

It’s not just a selection of levels present, as there are lots of things to discover – towns, shops, mini-games, extra bosses, and even whole levels. It’s a shovel full of classic gaming goodness that anyone who likes platformers ought to give a try.

It’s all accompanied by a stellar soundtrack by Jake Kaufman (who has worked on WayForward’s Shantae franchise among other games). One of the few gaming soundtracks to have endured in the consciousness of gamers in recent memory, it still holds up well in 2017, three years after its initial release. It’s catchy enough to emulate the classics of the 8-bit era and blend in well with the game.

Yacht Club Games have even added a few things to Treasure Trove. Firstly, there is now a Body Swap mode, inspired by an episode of Adventure Time and the concept behind Ms. Pacman. You can now select the gender of all the main characters, ranging from Shovel Knight, the Order of No Quarter, and even the final boss. It’s a very inclusive addition that’s as customisable as you’d want it to be and the new sprites are well designed.

Cooperative mode is now available for all non-handheld platforms, no longer requiring the Shovel Knight amiibo for Wii U. While the levelling up mechanic is still amiibo exclusive for the time being, Yacht Club Games have included the Shovel Knight Fairy to accompany your character across three games. It doesn’t actually do anything major, but it at least highlights any treasure you might have missed.

As a fan of the initial game, I was pretty excited to see that the support for the game would continue with meaningful content; with all campaigns included in the Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove being made available separately as well. There are three campaigns available for the collection thus far, with a fourth one featuring King Knight as a playable character on the horizon and a 4-player Battle Mode still to come this year.

Plague of Shadows is Plague Knight’s DLC, sporting a new character with an explosive move-set. Differences in level design to accompany his abilities better keep the game fresh. Plague Knight is somewhat difficult to control, but has an array of potions to be created, such as one to temporarily increase his life bar. As a side-story, it’s a welcome addition, even if Plague Knight’s abilities take some getting used to.

The marquee mode in Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove is the brand new prequel campaign: “Specter of Torment”. Unlike Plague of Shadows, Specter of Torment feels like its own game with heavily redesigned levels, new enemies, new boss battle variants, and even a meaningful backstory showing how Specter Knight came into the service of The Enchantress. Jake Kaufman has even remixed the entire soundtrack to keep the game feeling like a new experience. In short, it’s wonderful.

Specter Knight controls wonderfully, though his aerial dash slash might take some getting used to. However, by finding red skulls in levels and trading them in at the fortress, Specter Knight can gain access to some really powerful sub-weapons, including the ability to heal. He can also channel his inner skateboarder by using his scythe to grind on rails.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
  [*]Stuffed full with three great campaigns
  [*]Masterful soundtracks from Jake Kaufman
  [*]Spectre Knight’s campaign feels like a true prequel
  [*]Cooperative mode now available for all without needing an amiibo
[/list]
[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
  [*]Plague Knight has a steep learning curve
  [*]Having to wait for King Knight’s campaign
  [*]Retro aesthetic may put off some people
[/list]
While the original game was a fabulous romp, the Treasure Trove collection is more than worthy of investing some time into. Anyone who already has the original will obtain the upgraded package for free, but if bought separately, each of the three released campaigns should keep you entertained with great platforming that’s full of charm. With more stuff coming in the next year, the Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove is worth its weight in gold.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

139488516.review:
Hail, noble adventurer! I, King Knight, ruler of Pridemoor Keep and valiant knight of the Shovel Knight realm, am here to regale you with my resplendent review of the legendary game, Shovel Knight.

From the moment I took up my royal scepter and embarked on this grand pixelated quest, I was enraptured by the magnificence that is Shovel Knight. This enchanting game, developed by Yacht Club Games, seamlessly combines the best elements of classic 8-bit platformers with a modern twist, crafting a masterpiece that truly stands the test of time.

First and foremost, let us speak of the gameplay. As I, King Knight, leaped, dashed, and gracefully descended upon my foes with my kingly staff, I felt a rush of exhilaration like no other. The controls are impeccably precise, allowing for both seasoned adventurers and newcomers to seamlessly master the art of shovel-wielding combat. Each stage is meticulously designed, presenting unique challenges and introducing a colorful cast of adversaries that will put your mettle to the test.

The level of craftsmanship poured into every aspect of Shovel Knight is astounding. The art style is a glorious homage to the bygone era of 8-bit gaming, capturing the nostalgia of retro platformers while incorporating modern flair. The attention to detail in each pixel, each animated sprite, and each stunning backdrop is a testament to the dedication of the developers. The soundtrack, composed by Jake Kaufman, is a symphony of chiptune melodies that evoke a sense of adventure and heroism, making each step of the journey even more enthralling.

Speaking of the journey, the narrative of Shovel Knight is a tale woven with charm, wit, and a dash of royal panache. As players traverse the diverse lands, encountering valiant knights, eccentric townsfolk, and even treacherous bosses, they will be captivated by the heartwarming story that unfolds. The character development is remarkable, and even I, King Knight, found myself invested in the triumphs and tribulations of my fellow knights.

But what truly sets Shovel Knight apart from its contemporaries is its commitment to providing a wealth of content. From the original Shovel Knight campaign, aptly named "Shovel of Hope," to the subsequent expansions like "Plague of Shadows," "Specter of Torment," and "King of Cards," each adding a unique perspective to the overall story, players are granted hours upon hours of regal enjoyment. And let us not forget the challenge-filled gauntlet that is "Shovel Knight Showdown," a competitive multiplayer mode that allows knights to test their skills against one another.

In conclusion, my loyal subjects, Shovel Knight is a game fit for kings and queens alike. Its splendid gameplay, meticulously crafted visuals, enchanting soundtrack, and captivating story make it an unforgettable adventure that will stand the test of time. Whether you are a seasoned knight or a newcomer to the realm of gaming, I wholeheartedly recommend embarking on this legendary quest. Long live Shovel Knight!

138900780.review:
Mi juego preferido numero 1 de todos diría.

El soundtrack esta hecho por el hijoderemil de Jake Kaufman (virt) y tiene puros bangers, temazo tras temazo que encima en los dlc te hacen unas versiones alternas q tambien te dejan el opite dado vuelta. Aparte es como el ápice del chiptune corte desde temas re punchi hasta fucking música clásica académica craneada a la perfección, el tipo no falla una. Me quedan pendientes jugar al Shovel Knight Dig y Pocket Dungeon pero el soundtrack de esos también es increíble.

Después tenes el juego que bueno, también, plataformero de 5 estrellas. Todas las mecánicas e items son divertidos y tiene la flexibilidad de que podes ir eligiendo los bosses que vas peleando (medio como el megaman obvio). Podes pasarte el juego comprando todo o podes ir con la pichulita al aire y cagar a palazos literalmente a todos (también como el megaman, ir full limonero). Otra desición de diseño que es god es el hecho de poder romper los checkpoints para ganar guita y la gilada esa de que si te moris podes recuperar la plata pero tenes que volverte a meter en ese lio de cuanto de moriste.

Gráficamente otro win, los stages son hermosos y el spirtework también, desde los bosses y enemigos hasta los npcs de las aldeas. Hablando de estos NPC's, el juego tiene un humor bastante boludo (con muchos juegos de palabras) pero que banco a full. Boludeces como el hecho de que seas un paladín (pala-din) y los mil y un chistes pelotudos del sapo croador ese (que encima te da el logro de sapiencia) hacen que te cagues de risa cada tanto. [Increíblemente con el idioma en español los chistes pegan, no se si los habrán reescrito o si justo se traducían bien también, un día tengo que jugarlo en ingles y ver que onda].

La historia está, tampoco es la gran cosa pero bueno es un plataformero que carajo queres. Igual es bonita y en los dlc's te cuentan un poco de lore de un par de jefes.

Sobre los DLC la verdad es que son muy buenos todos, te permiten jugar como 3 de los bosses de la orden sin cuartel lo cual esta buenisimo, el peak es Specter of Torment (el soundtrack en este se va al carajo mal y aparte la mecanica es re divertida) pero cada uno tiene su cosa piola. Para empezar si tenias el juego base desde el principio (antes que salga el Treasure Trove y Specter of Torment salga standalone) te regalaban los DLC, golazo mal. De todas formas pagaría sin problemas ya que todos te cambian completamente la forma de jugar y te meten mas lore y boludeces (algunos hasta tienen modos de juegos extra como el King of Cards que trae un juego de cartas llamado Joustus que esta bastante entretenido).

Como extra el juego tiene muchas boludeces para toquetear y cambiar que estan buenas corte poner cheats dependiendo el nombre que te pongas en el savegame que hacen varios efectos (cambiarte el color, darte guita, god mode y hasta un modo culo que te remplaza palabras como pala, shovel o knight por culo) o una opcion de body swap para elegir y cambiar el genero de cada uno de los PJ del juego (y hacer realidad tus fantasías lesbicas o gays entre shovel y shield knight).

En fin, de los indies creo que es el mejor y de los juegos en general seria el mejor también si no fuese porque existe el Tony Hawks 4.

No se cuanto vale en tu region pero compralo igual es un juegazo vale la pena al 100%

A love letter to classic NES-era side scrolling platformers, Shovel Knight is a blast to play. With excellent music to accompany the retro style pixel graphics, you will be transported back to your couch, playing on a CRT TV in a game which offers a mix of Duck Tales, Castlevania and Megaman among other greats of that era.

The gameplay is overall very solid, the Mario-like map is a beautiful nod, there are enough variety and gimmicks througout the different stages, some are heavier on platforming, some are more focused on battle, enemy variety is good, hidden chambers everywhere, gold and collectables you can use in a Castlevania 2 -kind of town to upgrade your health and magic among others, boss fights that evoke that Megaman feeling...I loved the fact that certain stages or battles get much more manageable with certain upgrades (called Relics, or other names depending on the campaign) which gives you room to experiment and try to break certain hurdles the game throws at you.

Shovel Knight is brimming with content as well, offering 4 different campaigns, each of them taking abut 6-8 hours to complete.

So far I have beaten the first two (Shovel Knight and Plague Knight) and I sure plan to get back to play the other ones.

Solid higher 8 low 9/10 game, and one of those Steam games that should be in your library.

135187983.review:
This game is a collection of 5 shovel knight games, 4 of which being platformers and 1 being a brawler/fighting game. The shovel knight series are some the best platforming games ever made. It is very simple but leaves a lot of room for experimentation and execution. Movement feels great, the story is limited but charming and unique, and the music and level design are top notch.

I can't be positive enough about this series. That being said there are some negatives here. The original game can be a bit simple and can take a bit of getting used to because the method of combat is pretty different from a lot of games. Plague of shadows has very awkward controls and is for the most part the same as the original game with the main difference being a different playable character. And the card game mini game in king of cards can take away from the main game.

That being said those are mainly nitpicks from me. If you look at the entire package here this game is absolutely worth it even at its base asking point. The base game is dry but still a great high quality platformer with little filler, plague of shadows isn't my cup of tea but its a nice extra, Spectre of torment is one of the most fun games I have ever played with extremely fluid movement, and king of cards offers some of the most chaotic and fun platforming out there making you look at shovel knights mechanics in a completely new way. The fighting game/brawler is something I didn't experience and I don't care about too much but its also a nice extra on top of the 3 platformers I do like.

Especially Spectre of torment and King of cards are honestly worth the price of admission. These campaigns are way different from the original game, they have new playable characters and new levels. In these campaigns are some extremely creative and fun levels and power ups. Even just the base movement in those campaigns is something radically different and extremely fluid and fun.

I highly recommend this game and if you dislike one campaign try another just to see what those are like. I think anyone can find something here to enjoy and thats why I will absolutely recommend this.

134876531.review:
Played on Steam Deck, works like a charm.

Shovel Knight is one of those games that on the surface look very polished and fun but which ends up being somewhat of a letdown.

SK is a collection of NES-era tropes with a similar moveset and gameplay as Duck Tales, Megaman, Super Mario and such. It's unfortunate that it never quite reaches the same quality as its predecessors. The level design is, to put it short, uninspired and boring. Something felt off with controlling the Knight but I can't really put my finger to it, just something that I noticed when the game expects absolute precision in movement. The music is chirpy-chiptune but none of the beats truly make your foot tap. Pixel art is gorgeous at some scenes and lackluster in others, like in the level backgrounds. 

One of my biggest gripes was the "humor" of the game. SK doesn't seem to know if it's trying to be funny or serious. Some lines are so close being funny that they left a strange taste in my mouth. It's pretty hard to describe but the overall atmosphere is just... stale. 

The whole experience is riddled by the feeling of mediocrity and at two hours time I didn't feel any incentive to keep going, I just wasn't having fun. It feels like that better version of this game has been seen before. Maybe it's a semi-decent game if you don't have prior knowledge of platformers of yore, maybe. 

The review could've tipped both ways but ultimately I feel that the experience is not solid enough. I've wanted to try SK for a long time and felt disappointed. Maybe my expectations were too high.

133668771.review:
Shovel Knight really deserves all the praise it gets, it goes so far beyond just retro nostalgia, it's everything that worked about your favorite classic 2D platformers bumped to an 11, with TONS of content, including (but limited to) 4 entire game campaigns that are each fully fleshed out and unique in their own right, telling a really engaging story filled with charming characters, visuals, and a stylistic identity unmatched by its peers. It's oozing with depth and substance for anyone willing to pick it up and give it a shot, making it one of the most complete packages of 2D platformers out there, wonderful experience from top to bottom with memorable characters, soundtrack and visuals that earns its spot amongst the most iconic indie games of all time.

I cannot recommend it enough to literally anyone who can be mildly interested in dipping their toes into the indie gaming scene, and a must-play for any fans of the platforming genre in general.

For the amount of content you'd get, its absolutely a steal!

That being said, I think this is THE PERFECT RETRO GAME, and every fix would come to the cost of removing that feeling of old school gaming. Make the art/music cleaner will ruin the appealing 8-bit aesthetic, make the gameplay and mechanics smoother and you'll ruin that punishing yet very rewarding feeling old school platformers had (It already kinda felt like a 16-bit game in later campaigns), and making the characters and story more complex will ruin the beauty of that simple yet charming writing of simpler times. Not my idea of fun making the game annoying is not the same as if they had just made it hard, and I'm honestly just not as accepting of pitch black levels or systemically unpredictable enemy movements as children playing games in the 90s were. This game does not need to artificially inflate the time to beat the game through repetition, there is enough content as it is.
  Played a fair bit more of this on Switch and since I think I got this on PC via a humble bundle or something I thought I'd try it again to see if I was just tripping before. I was not. 129211155.review:
There's a reason Shovel Knight kicked off the success of indie games.  It's really damn good.  Great controls, great level design, great boss battles, great music...honestly it's got it all.  The game is really well done.  It even has a fairly interesting story even though it doesn't need one for the style of game it was going for.   Now, that's not to say it doesn't have its flaws, but they're really few and far in between.  My biggest gripes in this game are that some of the pits seem like you'll land in them unless you've played the game before.  There is definitely some BS parts, especially on the final boss where there are pits you can get knocked back into.  Still, overall the game is great.


This review is mostly for the original Shovel Knight game Shovel of Hope, since I haven't really done much of the DLC.  I'm not the biggest fan of Plague Knight's DLC so far, as he doesn't feel particularly good to control, but we'll see how things go.  I've managed to unlock every achievement in the base game...and I have to say that the game can begin to lose some of it's charm as you do the more challenging achievements, but that's par for the course if you're trying to complete something.


Tips: So this'll be very slight spoilers, but I thought I'd offer some tips for those playing the game for the first time.  Firstly, the shovel pogo Shovel Knight can do, does NOT require you to hold down.  Tapping down once will start the animation and you won't leave this pogo form until you hit solid ground or you attack in midair.  It's important to understand that you don't need to hold down.  When I first started playing I was holding down because I thought I needed to hold down, and it made bouncing around more difficult to control.  You simply tap down once and then move however you need.


As far as doing upgrades, you'll eventually have more than enough money to get everything, but if you're wondering what to purchase first you should definitely concentrate on meal tickets to get health upgrades.  More health makes the levels much easier.  Magic is helpful too, but health is the priority.  When you can upgrade your shovel or armor, I'd grab the silver armor first.  It has a neat function where it gives you a charge slash after you pogo twice in a row.  Since charge slashes are double damage this means you can kill things quicker.  The only shovel upgrade you should prioritize is the charge slash itself, although I'd get it after the silver armor personally.  As for relics I think you should grab the phase locket as soon as you can.  Invincibility is a powerful effect and definitely helps with harder sections of the game and in boss fights.  Buying the 2 chalices in the first town's basement should also be a priority as you can fill them for free with health potions that'll give you more life to survive especially in boss fights.

I'm late to the party on this one, so what is there to say that hasn't already been said? This is a masterfully crafted retro platformer that does everything right, providing essentially four games in one, with each campaign having its own character with unique movement and combat mechanics, collectibles, and hub areas. The only real criticism I could level at it is that the Plague Knight campaign reuses the levels from the original game, but even that feels like nitpicking when taken in the context of the full package. Besides, I still thoroughly enjoyed blasting my way through those levels with Plague Knight. Shovel Knight has fully earned its place in the indie canon, and you won't go wrong purchasing it.

There is one thing I feel I need to express - even compared to the high standards set by the previous campaigns, I was thoroughly impressed by King of Cards, the final campaign. It really goes to show how much the developers honed their craft by working on the same game for so long. I look forward to their next project.

128872333.review:
[b] Shovel Knight Treasure Trove[/b] is a great game and a must-have 
for platformer/metroidvania/side-scroller fans. 
With its 4 unique campaigns you're sure to find one that you will enjoy. Having completed all of them, I'd like to share my in-depth thoughts for each campaign and help you find out which of them might be best for you and if you should pick up this game.

[b] Shovel of Hope : [/b]
In this campaign we play as a titular hero - Shovel Knight. This is probably the first campaign people start when they pick up the game and what can I say? I really enjoyed it.

Shovel Knight's moveset is easy to grasp and feels polished. His simple moveset is complemented by relics, which give players a lot of unique abilities and make the character skillset feel complete. Combat and platforming experience feels good, but I think the combat is a bit better. Shovel Knight also has some of the coolest boss-fights I've got to play, really well-designed and challenging in a fair way. 

The ost's are catchy and I really like the retro-colored pixel art-style. Story - it is quite simple, but in a good way and I think it fits game's general lighthearted aesthetic

The only critique I really have is that while difficulty is fair 
throughout, there is one thing that feels simply unfair. Upon death Shovel Knight drops bags of gold that he can retrieve, but sometimes they can get stuck somewhere simply unreachable, which can get really frustrating. I recommend spending your gold on items before accessing certain levels so that you won't lose your time. This applies to all the campaigns.


[b]  Plague of Shadows : [/b] 
This one was a tough start for me, but after some time I think it's pretty good. Level-wise it is unfortunately the least unique campaign since you mostly play throughout the same levels as Shovel Knight that are slightly modified to fit the Plague Knight's playstyle.

Speaking of his playstyle - Plague Knight starts difficult to grasp. His platforming can be hard and frustrating, but it simply takes some time to master it. Contrary to level-design, his combat skillset might be one of the most unique and advanced in the entire game. Plague Knight can create different type of bombs using variety of casings, powders and fuses that  you can obtain. You can create a lot of cool bomb combinations and it is fun to try finding the best solutions for different situations. If you value freedom in your playstyle or you simply crave chaos, then I definitely recommend this campaign for you.

Plague Knight's combat and healing capabilities make most boss fights a breeze. Unlike combat, you won't find as much ease in Plague Knight's platforming - it is really a mixed bag in my opinion,  had some of the most frustrating moments in the game, but once you master it, it's manageable, but still I wouldn't call it fun.

I really enjoyed this campaign's story and I think it's sweet. Basically you're seeing the same world from a new perspective and embark on your own quest as Plague Knight. There's also a really cool, unique hub area.

[b] Specter of Torment : [/b] 
It is the shortest campaign in the game, but also one of my favorites. Specter of Torment is a must-play for those looking for platforming-focused gameplay. It has some of the most fun and dynamic platforming in the entire game!

Specter Knight's combat also feels really good, it's satisfying and effective. Similarly to Shovel Knight, Specter Knight's moveset is complemented by curios (his version of relics). His curios are a great addition and I like how the game gives you a little area to test them out after purchasing them.

Unlike Plague of Shadows - Specter of Torment stages are noticably different from their original iterations and some are completely new, which feels really refreshing. Additionally stages have new enemies and some of the bosses have new attacks unique to this campaign! Stages also have remixed version of original music tracks. 
+ Specter Knight's hub world is amazing!

I absolutely enjoyed this campaign story - it's interesting and really tragic. Specter Knight is probably one of the most engrossing characters in the game.

Overall I highly recommend this campaign, it is the most polished and fun.

[b]  King of Cards :[/b] 
This one was also a tough start for me, but oh boy did it change. By the end of my playthrough it became one of my favorite campaigns!

King Knight is the most unique and also the funniest campaign in the game. His gameplay consists of two parts normal stages and card game called Joustus. At first I was really skeptical about both of them, but it just took me some time to warm up to them.

Let's start with his platforming. I'll be honest - at first it felt really rough and I hated it, but after finishing the game I think I can say that he has the second best platforming moveset and some of the best platforming sections in the entire game! His platforming moveset is really simple, but it works extremely well and is really fun (especially in mid- and end-game).

His combat is also simple, but yet again works really well. Just like the previous campaigns, his skillset is complemented by heirlooms (King Knight's equivalent of relics) and I've got to admit - heirlooms are one of the best and funniest ability items. King of Cards also has few new, unique boss-fights, some of which
being the most fast-paced and difficult in the entire game.

The second half of King of Cards gameplay consists of the card game Joustus, in which you have to claim more gems than your opponent by pushing your cards onto the gems. Each card has arrows which indicate the direction they can push other cards and some have unique abilities. At first it felt really mediocre to me, but once I grasped the mechanics it 
just kept on getting better. Strategizing, finding the best possible play, predicting your opponent's moves was all really satisfying and fun to me. But I have to admit that some of these card were really difficult and undeniably frustrating at times. Still, I think winning some of them even after 10 tries was worth the struggle.

Design-wise King of Cards has the most unique levels and some are completely new, previously unexplored parts/locations in the world of Shovel Knight. One thing some might find negative is that his levels were all relatively short, I personally also disliked that at first, but I quickly changed my mind - I think short length stages fit King Knight play-style 
better and considering that his campaign has an entirely fleshed-out 
card-game, it only seems fair that the stages are shorter.

Okay now let me tell you about the best part of this game - King Knight himself! This guy is the most charming and entertaining fellow in this entire game, his story was such a spectatle to follow. Some of the cutscenes and character interactions made me laugh multiple times. 
To sum it up King of Cards story has a lot of personality and is sure to keep you engaged.

Overall I recommend this campaign if you're looking for an unique challenge and difficult, 
but fun platforming stages.


[b] Showdown : [/b] 
This multiplayer mode is really chaotic and fun. It doesn't have an online co-op, but you can still play it together with friends via Steam Remote Play and the experience is still really good if you have good internet connection and if not, playing against CPU is still a lot of fun! 
There's also a story mode and other modes that you can play.

128237406.review:
This is only a review of Shovel of Hope and Showdown games in from this pack, since I haven't played others yet.

Shovel of Hope is the main game of the Shovel Knight series. It's about 8 hours of pure 2D NES-talgia style platforming. And I'm not sure how much I like it. Nowadays you can get tons of high quality metroidvanias(this is not one) and platform games with both pixel-art and non-pixel art. Not to mention there are collections of real classic NES platform games, like Mega Man Legacy collection, which costs half of this and often goes to discount to fraction of this game.

If you're on edge about Shovel Knight I suggest getting the standalone version of Shovel of Hope - it's much cheaper. But if you end up loving it you will have to buy it at piece-meal prices and you'll pay more overall. Too bad they don't provide discount on Treasure Trove if you own some of the games.

Now, how was Treasure Trove? It was OK. It was obviously a kickstarter game. You run into stuff that looks and feels like a stretch goal. There's a level with faces of biggest money spenders, there's few bosses that come out of nowhere and probably were added as a bonus. The game ends up having a lot of stuff in it, but it's kinda disjointed. The difficulty curve is all off, the first stages are the hardest, then middle game is a snooze-fest, then end-game is stress-filled joy-killing irritating machine of 1-block wide jumps in total darkness with knock-back monsters flying around. It's never really that hard, but it does get frustrating at moments.

I didn't like how Shovel Knight plays too much. Attacking anyone with Shovel gives YOU so much knock-back you can easily knock yourself off the platform you're standing on. That makes fights where you can't jump real pain, slow, and just boring. There's an armor that lowers this knock back, but even then it's not really fun. 

You can jump at enemies pogo-style, like in Ducktales, but most of the monsters are designed in a way to make sure you'll almost never combo multiple hits. They'll quickly dodge second hit too far for you to reach, or block their head etc. I would be fine with just some monsters doing that, or monsters later on, but I found myself almost never really being able to just have some fun, even in early stages, when revisiting them. 

You also have some magic items you'll collect along the way. They are fun, and useful... Not as useful as alternate weapons in Mega Man 11, but useful enough. The issue is, they made sure you won't have fun unlocking them. When you find a chest with magic item you get a price on it, and you have to pay. If you can't pay for it on the spot you will be able to later find it in town... at increased price. It happened to me only once, I was few coins away, but it was very frustrating.

This game has souls-like system, where you have infinite lives, but you lose some of your gold when you die. The gold can be then recovered if you reach the same spot. In theory that is. In my experience this almost never works as intended. The balloons with gold fly off randomly, and often end up in places where you won't be able to jump without dying... or just unreachable even with best tricks. There's one item that can suck treasures towards you, but it takes the same slot as potent healing potion, so it's hard to carry around. Often you'll die by falling into a hole in the most dangerous part of the map, and the cash will be floating where you died - with no hope of retrieval. Even though money doesn't matter that much in this game and you can easily farm it it's really irritating to see your cash permanently lost in a system where in theory you should be able to get it back. That's just one additional small thing to be frustrated with.

There are also some stages that will make everything black, so you have to move in the darkness. And I don't know what they did with this effect, but whenever it was on screen it made me nauseous and I could barely play. I had to pause the game every few minutes in order not to puke. Similar to playing a VR game, but without VR. I don't think I'm photosensitive, no other 2D game ever had this kind of effect on me in my 30 years of gaming.

Or they add fast travel at some point... But it's slower than actually using the map, so I don't see what's the point.

At some points random(?) 4 bosses will appear on the map. I don't know if the order is preset, but the first one I got was the hardest of them all by far. All other 3 were pushovers I defeated on first go. This game has other bad decisions. It has MM style boss rush near the end... but if MM can be excused by tradition... in this game boss rush really adds nothing and just wastes your time. Unless you're doing some kind of challenge run I guess...

Well, I can see this is a fine game, and for some players it might be awesome. There are a lot of funny NPCs in town, there's tons of bosses to defeat, many stages can be repeated as bonus stages to gather cash. You have armors and skills to collect. Overall it's not bad, but it took me some breaks before I forced myself to finish. Where for example MM11 I got trough in one sitting and couldn't put my controller away.

There's just something in this game play that doesn't mesh well with me. As I mentioned - start with Shovel of Hope standalone. I really wish I did, I would have saved money. I thought I would love the series, due to all the acclaim it has.

I also tried Showdown mode, which is full-fledged Smash-bros-like fighter. With story modes for all fighters, different fight conditions and so on. It's much more robust than I've expected, and I had fun with it. It's very good, and I would actually rate it higher than the main game. You can select multiple colors AND genders for each character (you can actually change genders of all characters even in Shovel of Hope). The thing is though... I have better fighting games that I will always run over this mode when I play with friends. 

There are 3 other story games in this. One contains the same levels, but different character. The two others are completely original. I think one of them is kind of card game? I haven't tried them, so I can't comment on it yet. This makes for a good amount of games in one pack, but Disney Afternoon Collection also contains many good games, and can be much cheaper. There are many other 2D platform games on Steam that, both oldies and indies, that could be better for you. Shantae is great. Gunvolt series. Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth. Momodora series. And many, many others to choose from.

127047100.review:
I am so sad that I didn't like this game. 

I had really high hopes, and some of that did pay off, but mostly I was frustrated with the level designs and the constant instant-death mechanics (spikes kill you on 1 hit; if you fall into a hole you die instantly; enemies push you into spikes or holes and you die instantly).

I think that the developers wanted to make a "difficult retro platformer" but in the end most of the end-game levels were unbearable.
The last 2 stages seemed like a parody of the game - every wall full of spikes, holes everywhere, enemies that are there just and only to be frustrating.

The first 2 hours were very enjoyable and I loved going through the different stages, meeting NPCs and progressing the story.
But around the half-way mark, the "difficulty" suddenly spiked - every screen has to have at least 3 instant-death mechanics.
From that point forward, at the end of each level, more than anything else, I felt more relieved that I don't have to play through that again.

The art direction is great - the graphics and the music hit the exact spot that they were aiming for.
The story and dialogue is also very good and the character design fits the world.
Even the boss designs and mechanics were interesting and not frustrating - they were what I would call actually difficult, instead of instant-death "difficult".
If only the game had 1/10th of the spikes and holes everywhere.

After finishing the campaign, I'm glad that I don't have to suffer through some of these levels again.

I don't know if I'll come back for the DLCs.

125449126.review:
I'd had Shovel Knight on my Steam wishlist since the day it came out. Here we are, 8 years later, I finally got to play the legendary indie title. I played through all four campaigns on the Steam Deck, mostly while on the road. Shovel drop, bomb burst, dash slash, and shoulder bash your way through the 4 "Treasure Trove" campaigns. Get knocked-back into bottomless pits or nipped by spikes and die many many times. The gameplay can be hard, but it's a rewarding experience.

[b]Shovel of Hope[/b] - The game that started it all. I found Shovel Knight's campaign to be fantastic and the most challenging, but it's definitely the one that should be played first. The reason for this is that Shovel Knight himself is far more limited in traversal capabilities when compared to the other campaign protagonists. You can really only walk, jump, and shovel drop, which while fun to figure out, leaves little room for error. Story wise, Shovel Knight is rather independent outside of a few story beats near the beginning and end of the game, but it makes sense given what the ultimate goal is.

[b]Plague of Shadows[/b] - Plague Knight is lots of fun to control. Go through nearly the same exact levels as Shovel Knight in an alternate storyline that runs parallel to Shovel of Hope. Watch as Plague Knight effortlessly launches across gaps that would have required precise shovel drop combos in the first campaign. The combat is spammy, the mobility is uncanny, and the story is somewhat hammy. More NPCs get to shine in this one. Really enjoyed Plague of Shadows, very forgiving relative to Shovel of Hope.

[b]Specter of Torment[/b] - The first expansion with entirely new levels. Specter Knight's story is basically the tragic tale of his sorry state. The [i]cool factor[/i] here is dialed up to 11 as you combo midair dash-slashes and rail grinding. There are also flashback missions in which you get to play as his former self, which I thought was cool too. The character is unapologetically edgy despite being surrounded by allies and friends, but he's an unwilling, semi-dead servant to a corrupt dictator, so it checks out.

[b]King of Cards[/b] - I don't know if it was the shoulder bashing and spin jumping, the shorter stages in place of full levels, the (almost) endearing story, or the newly introduced card game, but I enjoyed King Knight's campaign most of all. Joustus is the SK universe's equivalent to Gwent, in that it's a unique card game that everyone plays all of a sudden. While kind of tough to get into and used to, Joustus becomes quite fun when you get a deck that can win consistently. Play as the smartest dumbest narcissist in the world as he amasses an airship's worth of friends and rivals. Challenge hardened warriors to games of cards and challenge card-playing kings to fist fights.

Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove provides immense value and I regret not buying it much sooner. (I have not yet played the battle mode, "Showdown", but it's looking like more of a multiplayer thing.) For better, and [i]sometimes[/i] worse, it's an unrelenting homage to the NES/SNES days; when gaming was the furthest thing from creatively bankrupt.

125388569.review:
It's a shame the review has to be thumbs up or thumbs down, based only on recommendation.  There's a lot of to love here: the imagination, humor, music, and art design are all fantastic.  The commitment to updating the game across years with content at no charge to early adopters is an admirable model for the industry, and these developers were pioneers in embracing it. 

But recommending Shovel Knight is very, very situational. The game worships an outdated game design from when hour-long games needed to be ridiculously difficult to pad out gameplay.  There's a type of gamer who thrives on the anxiety and frustration built in to such games, which fuels them to keep playing. As gaming evolved to be more accommodating and reasonable, most games adopted hard modes to keep appealing to them.  There is no such toggle here.  While there's no live system, the promise of unlimited continues is used here as a band-aid on a level design philosophy from the NES-hard era of games.  Many flying/floating enemies are programmed to approach and attack from angles you cannot, leaving no way to defend yourself without taking damage. Levels feel built for pixel-perfect reflexes, while the developers reward that play with tricks and traps at every turn.

If you enjoy the "Get good" creed, then you'll enjoy this game.  I don't, and can't recommend this game to anyone who plays games to relax and have fun.

Dream game for people with 90's nostalgia. If you're not part of that audience, you will probably still enjoy the games included but for me that gimmick got old after Shovel of Hope, which I believe is the only game worth playing out of the bunch.

Plague of Shadows repeats Shovel of Hope's level design to the point where it's no surprise that there's no listing for it on Steam. Not to mention the terrible controls.
Specter of Torment has better controls in exchange for worse combat, and it tries having a "serious" story that I could not care less about.
King of Cards is the best of the three sequels, too bad it decides to put a lot of its focus on a card game.

I wanted to like this game so much but I'm clearly in the minority that didn't.

Esto, gracias a las habilidades que se van desbloqueando. Parece ser del tipo de juego que permite llegar a la misma conclusión, yendo por varios caminos distintos. Eso me parece muy positivo. Ya después probé la campaña del químico y vi que se mejoraron varios aspectos de usabilidad, pero no la jugué lo suficientemente aún. Por lo pronto, y con lo que jugué, puedo decir que vale la pena totalmente. Me gustaría probar el modo cooperativo, que es algo que originalmente no tenía y puede ser bastante entretenido.

This game is truly something special. These are 5 varied games filled with hours of content to enjoy.  It has great level design, an amazing soundtrack, and plenty of things to do. While I really enjoyed Shovel of Hope, Specter of Torment improved on nearly everything. As for Kind of Cards, it's a fun more varied adventure with a card game that's pretty hard to master. I wouldn't say it's as good as the other two, but still a fun time. 

Unfortunately, I'm not a big fan of Plague of Shadows as Plague Knight doesn't control in an intuitive way and the game is way too similar to Shovel of Hope. The last game included, Shovel Knight Showdown, is very different from the rest. It's a fighting game that functions a lot like Smash Bros. It's not my cup of tea, yet I can still recognize how well made it is. It's filled to the brim with unlocables and has a ton of variety with the plethora of playable characters. Overall, this is one masterful collection of games that is well worth the price even for Plague of Shadows shortcomings.

Instant death no matter how much health you have left just because you took one hit from an enemy that knocked you into a pit or some spikes is no longer okay.  That's a relic from the arcade machines needing more quarters and it has no place in modern gaming.  But it happens in this game.

And also there's a big part of this game that involves whacking every wall because any one of them could be hiding any of the in-game collectables with no indication that that wall is worth whacking.  You literally have to whack all of them (or refer to a guide to tell you which ones are actually worth whacking).  That's another big nono.

This game has so much going for it.  The gender/pronoun inclusivity.  The sidescrolling action that rewards you for doing away with checkpoints.  And so many other things that I couldn't mention.

But its flaws far outweigh its good points.  Which is even more frustrating because the flaws could be easily fixed.  Treat falling into a pit or spikes as if it's a really powerful hit instead of instant death.  Make sure that every wall that reveals something when whacked has some kind of distinctive mark to indicate that.  Etcetera.

123151732.review:
After replaying Shovel of Hope for the umpteenth time, I have to say, the Shovel Knight collection is my favorite game of all time and, if you haven't played it, you're making a mistake.

Firstly, the art style. Sure, it's that 8-bit aesthetic, but with the charm and effort they put into these sprites, it's frankly amazing what they pull off. Not to mention how accurate it is to NES graphics, only limiting their color set to what the technology could handle...plus only a handful of colors to fit what they needed. Although, they didn't limit their technology, making it feel like an NES Game in terms of nostalgia, without the problematic technical limitations.

Secondly, the gameplay. Technically it's 4 games each with different controls, but all of them are great. There's the classic run-and-hit style of Shovel Knight, the chaotic and explosive gameplay of Plague Knight, the hack-n-slash Ninja Gaiden-esque thrill of Specter Knight, and the wacky Wario-like shoulder bashing of King Knight. All feel great with the levels painstakingly made to give a fair, yet tough challenge that makes you feel like a legend to pull off.Thirdly, the music. My god, the music. Sure, it's chiptune, but what they do with it is amazing. A Thousand Leagues Below, High Above the Land, In the Halls of the Usurper, and many more are all beautifully composed to match each level and give the perfect feel for each one. Not to mention, they literally remixed the 10 main level tracks for Specter of Torment, taking these already phenomenal tracks, and turning them into versions that are just as good as, if not better than their original counterparts.

Lastly, the story. From the classic adventure of Shovel of Hope and the goofy romance of Plague of Shadows, to the tragic drama of Specter of Torment and the silly misadventure of King of Cards, all four of these tales are great to experience and will show you four fantastic stories that all intertwine with unforgettable characters you will fall in love with.

(Plus there's Shovel Knight Showdown, but I kind of see that as just a bonus.)

In summary, Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove is exactly what it says it is. A treasure trove of quality games that the crew at Yacht Club Games poured their heart and soul into to make easily one of the greatest indie masterpieces of all time, leaving a mark on gaming history that will last the test of time.

As for getting it, don't worry. If you have a recent-ish console, you can get it. PC, Xbox 360-X/S, PS3-4 and the Vita, Nintendo Wii, Wii U, 2DS, 3DS, and Switch...plus probably some others I'm missing. Even when some of these consoles were obsolete, they got the full package anyways. It's available now for $40, which, while it is quite a bit, is basically getting 5 games for 8 bucks each, a steal in my opinion. So what are you waiting for? Dig into Shovel Knight and have a blast!

121086587.review:
I love this game. I like to think about 2D platformers as being in two different camps; one being the speed-focused kind where you can fly across the screen in one jump, and the other being the more chunky kind with a focus on microadjustments. The best example of the first kind would be Super Meat Boy, and the best example of the latter is Shovel Knight. 

The reason why I like to think about platformers this way is because I really disliked Super Meat Boy when I played it, I felt like the character was sliding all over the place and I felt a severe lack of control. Playing Shovel Knight, comparatively, fit me like a glove and I was able to pick up the game almost instantly. And yet there are (obviously) people who really vibe with Super Meat Boy and also people who really dislike the controls of Shovel Knight, and it wouldn't surprise me if those groups were linked. So, here's my point; if you're used to a platformer like Super Meat Boy (or other speed-focused platformers), then you might find Shovel Knight to be unresponsive in comparison. Getting from platform to platform requires you to hold down the directional button all the way through the jump in order to make it. On the flip side, you will rarely overshoot your target or slide into death faster than you can react to it. Your enjoyment of the game may very well depend on your preference, which is why I think it's important to point out.

With all of that said, let's get into what Shovel Knight has that is so special: the mix between careful and varied design. The level of craft and polish is almost extensive enough to be detrimental. Every screen has a clear path that makes sense from a glance, enemies are placed to be obstacles but also to be possible shortcuts by jumping on their heads, secrets are marked and placed at consistent intervals and places but never quite obvious enough to make it impossible to miss them. Every major area is half an hour long – what a thing to be able to say in a game – which is consistent enough that I could use it as a clock while playing. The game never breaks, has close to no bugs (I noticed a grand total of one, and it might not have been, I'm still not sure) and everything about the presentation is stellar, from music to animations to art style. 

If the polish makes the game clear and consistent, then the variety is where the fun comes from. That comes partially from the different environmental variations that exist between stages, like Megaman games in the past; icey floors, low gravity due to being underwater, wind currents etc. These are great for the same reasons why they're great in Megaman games, and bosses are similarly designed around these aspects as well. But on top of this there are other surprises. Suddenly you might have to fight a miniboss, sometimes there's an autoscrolling section that require you to speed up, sometimes it's both at once. The amount of times that the game manages to surprise you with its mechanics and challenges is wild, and it keeps things interesting to the end and across every expansion, which feature many of the same levels. Add to that the items you can find and buy, adding more options on the player side, and you have a game that never really gets old.

Or at least, not because of the content. Shovel Knight is known for being a difficult game, and a punishing one. You lose 25% of your currency when you die, even if it's retrievable, and it's entirely possible to exit a stage poorer than you entered it, despite the treasure you collect throughout. So, you might ask, is the difficulty overtuned? And I have to say... yeah. I think it is. There are options, some items that make certain sections easier, armor sets that make you drop half as much gold or give you more damage abilities. But even then, it's without a question a brutal game. There were times when I didn't think I would make it past an obstacle, banging my fist in the desk from pure frustration. Especially the end of the last expansion, King of Cards, feels like the developers were racing against player capabilities, making levels and bosses harder just for the sake of keeping their reputation for difficulty. 

The punishment is also too harsh, because the gold you lose don't just sit on the nearest platform; instead it gets thrown into the air in the shape of three balloons. These balloons can be, and often are, unreachable, either because you died in the middle of a high jump and they drift too high, or because they're floating just above a death drop. Even in Dark Souls, your souls are put in a location where you can easily take them back, as long as you can reach it again. In Shovel Knight, you often have to just cut your losses, because even if a balloon is technically retrievable, it might not be worth the risk.

You might wonder, why did I complete the game if it is so difficult? About a third of players who own this game do get to the ending of the base game, after all. Is it really that bad? And while it is, one thing that does keep you going is the story. It's a simple rescue story with a twist and a minimalistic one at that, but the way that they tell it is something special. I won't spoil too much, but the gameplay connected to the story together with the musical themes and the change of tone towards the end... it's all really good in a way that is hard to put your finger on. You really start to care about the characters of Shovel Knight, and to some extent the expansions as well. It leads to a drive to see the end, and a huge satisfaction when you reach it. This goes for every expansion except King of Cards, which I felt left on a pretty big downer.

Overall, Shovel Knight is a great game and one of my favorites. I love everything about it and I want more people to see it... which is why it's a shame that some people will hesitate because of the difficulty, perhaps rightfully so. I can only say that I recommend the game based on my own experience. If you're a fan of platformers and don't at least try this game out, you might just rob yourself of one of the best experiences there is in the genre. That is my opinion, at least.
