120924686.review:
As of this review I have 100%'ed:Shovel Of Hope, Plague Of Shadows, And Specter of Torment with the intention of 100%ing King of Cards and Showdown Later.

It's truly amazing to see how far this game has come, my first memories of it were back when I used to play shovel of hope on  my 3Ds, it was the first difficult game I was ever really exposed to and though it pissed me off at times, I was intrigued.

I'm going to review each of these games on their own because each of them are so unique.


SoH (9/10): Maybe it's just nostalgia but this is definitely up there for me as the best game in this pack, the controls are simple but fun, it's really fun to speedrun and it introduced us to an amazing cast of characters. 

PoS (7/10): While I hated the controls originally the platforming is really fun, especially if you're going fast which I feel is what Plague Knight is designed to do, the problem with this game is the amount of collectibles, and the reused level design, pretty much every level is the same as shovel of hope with a few changes here and there, reruns got old fast for achievements. I did enjoy the story even if it's just another love story, I felt like they did a better job of getting us to care about the relationship here more.

SoT (10/10) I love this game so much, arguably the best game in the series, Specter of torment introduces entirely new level design, a unique control scheme, and incredibly fun platforming, the music is remixed and amazing, and the story is peak in this game.

KoC (8/10) I wasn't huge on this game, King Knight just feels really clunky and weird to me, Joustus hurts my brain, and the story is realllllly stupid, seriously this game was based around some man-child wanting to become rich by playing a card game.

Showdown (9/10) I actually really enjoyed showdown, even if I didn't have anyone to play it with and getting the achievements will probably suck. Showdown's lets you play as pretty much every major character in the series and more, classic mode also gives us pretty unique interactions, the problem is this game is soo unbalanced, literally any heavy character is screwed.

Do I recommend this game? Absolutely, even if you aren't huge on hard games, this one is a good midway point to start for 30 USD you are definitely getting a great set of games.

120872537.review:
Shovel Knight is an enjoyable game. What Shovel Knight turned into, Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove, was not for me. The base game that was originally released, now called Shovel of Hope, is a fun game that's well made with a few caveats. I would recommend it at $15 by [url=store.steampowered.com/app/589500/Shovel_Knight_Shovel_of_Hope]clicking this link![/url] Save your money and just buy the base game. If you really want more, you're only paying $5 more in the end if you pay full price.

The game was added on to with "free" campaigns from Kickstarter stretch goals. Yacht Club Games over promised three new campaigns which became, Plague of Shadows, [url=store.steampowered.com/app/589510/Shovel_Knight_Specter_of_Torment]Specter of Torment[/url], [url=store.steampowered.com/app/1116780/Shovel_Knight_King_of_Cards]King of Cards[/url], and even a multiplayer fighting game called [url=store.steampowered.com/app/1116770/Shovel_Knight_Showdown]Showdown[/url]. Anyone that backed the game or purchased the retail release before a certain time got all this content for free and then the price was raised to $40. To be fair, and give YCG credit where credit is due, you can still purchase each of the campaigns à la carte except for Plague of Shadows which is included in Shovel of Hope, supposedly unlocked after you beat the main game, but I can not confirm that. (Some have said it simply isn't available separately.)

These campaigns took 5 years to make, tying YCG up from doing something fresh with their talent. The "new" campaigns use the same levels and sometimes are largely unchanged. The main difference is the moveset and controls of the other characters. The new characters don't really change the game, and are more like a remix. I'm sure opinions will differ, but I had my fill of "retro 8-bit NES action inspired largely by Capcom's DuckTales from ex-members of Wayforward, the studio that created Shantae" with the original Shovel Knight and just didn't enjoy the new characters enough to care. And if I didn't get far enough in the new campaigns to see a major difference, then I was still apathetic enough that I didn't care. I especially hated the play style for Plague of Shadows.

For me, there was just too much content I didn't want or ask for. Just because it's free doesn't mean it's added value worthy of your time. It's also been disappointing how much YCG has exploited Shovel Knight in cross-game cameos and merchandise. What was once a charming indie underdog story and a fun game, I now find unpleasant. I don't blame them; they have to pay the bills, but I hope I never have to see this tin can ever again. I 100% the main game and have never gone back.

120309062.review:
[b] Preface and Additional Notes: [/b]
I have actually owned the 3DS version of this game for a while now, and have spent the majority of my time there instead of on PC. I will also note that I am not nostalgic for the NES, SNES, or any retro gaming console really. I will also be reviewing this game as a whole package, not every game individually for the most part. But as for my opinion on that, four great games + a cute little side mode for only $40 is a total steal in my opinion. Last thing to note is that I really enjoy a good challenge in my games, and don't get frustrated at it generally. 

[b] Things I like: [/b]
First off, all of the pixel art is incredible. Every single sprite and background of every area looks great. I'm sure that this game is the entire reason some people tried out pixel art, which is a great thing. Secondly, the music is iconic. In fact, it's so iconic I'm willing to bet many people heard a song from this game before even knowing about it's existence. If you're a sucker for chiptune music, this game is your holy grail. Even for people who aren't, I'm sure they'll still like at least a few songs here. As for gameplay, I found it a total treat. Sure, it's difficult, but it's usually entirely fair, and even then I found the average difficulty level to be much more reasonable than most actual NES games. You can also to an extent decide your own difficulty by just choosing not to use some of the cheesier items. The game is also surprisingly long for something based off of NES games, but that may be just because there are 4 individual campaigns. Last thing I'll say is that even after beating the campaigns, there are still quite a few things to toy around with.

[b] Things I Don't Like/Things Other People Might Not Like: [/b]
The only thing I could personally say I genuinely didn't really like is that the side mode feels kind of boring. It's like Classic Mode from the Super Smash Brothers games, but with less variety. If you're trying to get 100%, you'll have to replay that mode quite a few times, and I personally found it to be a bit boring. Even then, it's just a side mode, and I didn't even dislike my time with the mode. The difficulty may be a turn off for a lot of people. While it's not too hard, it's still hard enough for me to see a decent amount of people getting mad with it, especially some of the harder achievements. I could also see some people getting bored with games trying to invoke NES/SNES nostalgia, but this game came out before that became the popular thing to do as far as I remember.

[b] Overview and Tl;dr [/b]
One of, if not the finest retro throwback games to ever exist, everything about this game is fantastic. I can't see too many real flaws with this game, most of them just being a matter of taste. Since there's 4 games + 1 side game packaged into one, and the whole package is $40, you can view it as paying $10 for each game individually, which I view as a total steal.

Tl;dr: Probably the best and most iconic retro throwback game, pick it up if you're okay with a decent challenge. While the side mode can get a bit repetitive, I'd say that each other game is will worth $10, which is effectively what you're paying for each of them.

118597837.review:
A mediocre and extremely frustrating platformer which doesn't deserve the immense amount of praise it gets. Although I don't think Shovel Knight is a bad game, I'd definitely not call it good either.

The base game - Shovel of Hope - is a typical "you're a good guy and you must save the world" story with zero world-building and character development. The only thing the game tells you is how the antagonists - the Enchantress and her Order of No Quarter - are bad and you have to stop them. That's 9 unique characters which could have been interesting had the developers put any effort in fleshing them out.

Plague of Shadows is the first and the laziest DLC out of the three. You play as Plague Knight (one of the antagonists) who's trying to create a potion capable of giving super powers to anyone who drinks it so that he can... ask his assistant out on a date. While the premise is silly, I like it much more than the cliche that Shovel of Hope is, and we actually get a little character development this time (but just a little, god forbid the developers actually try expanding the almost non-existent game lore). What's not as good here is the gameplay: this DLC is effectively a reskin of the base game. You play the same levels and beat the same bosses except now you throw bombs instead of swinging a shovel and you can jump higher. There's some variation in how your attack works due to bomb modifiers but this, obviously, doesn't change the fact that you're playing the same game all over again.

Specter of Torment is the second DLC, and, surprisingly, it's actually good. You play as Specter Knight (another antagonist) on his quest to recruit people into the Enchantress's Order of No Quarter. While the plot comes down to beating all the same bosses, the level layouts were changed, so there's at least some novelty in terms of gameplay, and what's more important, the developers actually managed to come up with a backstory for a whole one(!) character and explain a couple of things relevant to the plot of the main game - a massive achievement on their part.

King of Cards is the third and the most controversial DLC in my opinion. You play as King Knight (yet another antagonist) trying to become the King of Cards - the champion in a card game called Joustus. The levels layouts were changed once again (in fact, instead of having few long levels with a boss at the end like in the previous campaigns, there're many shorter levels which you have to simply run through now) for gameplay novelty, and the developers worked even more on the game lore this time, not only coming up with one(!) character backstory, but also doing some world-building which explains how some things came to be in the main story. Unfortunately, there's one thing that ruins the experience, and that is this DLC's main gimmick - Joustus. To put it shortly, it's a poorly designed and poorly balanced mini-game which seems rich in mechanics and content but at the same time feels like a cheap afterthought. Hopefully, you can ignore it and beat the campaign by playing only the regular platforming levels (although it's not clear that you can actually do so) but playing Joustus is required if you want to experience all of the available content.

(As for the Showdown "DLC", I'm not going to spend any time explaining anything in depth. It's a Super Smash Bros.-style fighting game in Shovel Knight universe, and all you need to know is that it is cancer. Showdown is such an atrocious piece of trash that by no means you should ever touch it.)

Now that I've walked through all the separate in-game campaigns, I'd like to talk about the thing that is common among all of them, the main design point of Shovel Knight - the attempt to make an "old-school" game, or, as the developers understand it, to make a very frustrating game:

[list]
 [*] many enemies are very annoying to deal with due to their movement and attack behavior
 [*] all the levels are riddled with instant-death traps (bottomless pits, lava pools, and spike floors/walls/ceilings)
 [*] getting hit stuns you shortly, which paired with the previous two points means you'll be dying a lot
 [*] in case you die, you drop money which has to be collected back, and in case you die again in the process, the old money bags disappear forever, which paired with the previous three points means you'll be losing a lot of money too if you're not good at platformers
 [*] Propeller Knight (and his level as a whole) in the Shovel of Hope/Plague of Shadows campaigns is the worst part of the game and was most likely created specifically to make you suffer
[/list]

Having achieved 100% completion in each campaign I don't think I can remember a single point where I found Shovel Knight satisfying. Either the game is so easy and boring (yet again thanks to how little effort was put into designing the story, the world, and its characters) that you feel apathetic about it, or it's so rage-inducing that you only feel relief after finally getting past some bullshit thrown in by the developers to make your life miserable.

117972391.review:
[IMPORTANT INFORMATION FOR THOSE LOOKING TO BUY THE GAME AT THE BOTTOM]

A collection of 4 fantastic games which host some of the most unique movesets for any platormers ever. 
[Shovel of Hope]
Shovel Knight is your standard experience, allowing players to tread carefully and duel all while keeping steady ground.
[Plague of Shadows]
 Plague Knight offers a sort of 'Richter Mode' to Shovel Knight's base game with an extreme amount of customization with a steep difficulty curve. 
[Specter of Torment]
Specter Knight is all about slick moves and aggressive combat, making his all new adventure all the more fun to learn. 
[King of Cards] King Knight's moveset is the simplest of all, described as the 'Plague Knight of Specter Knight' his story ended up as yet another Shovel Knight Sequel/Prequel with the most content of them all, with a larger variety of bite sized stages and encounters. 
[Showdown!]
Shovel Knight Showdown is also a fun way to duke it out, although kind of a shame you can't play with friends online. 

My only Gripe is that for whatever reason Plague of Shadows is ONLY available in Treasure Trove. Its not even available for DLC for Shovel of Hope nor even in the game. If you want to play Shovel Knight but still aren't sure if you'll love it I still think you should buy this, I ended up wasting money on Shovel of Hope, and I hope no one learns this the hard way.

I beat the game and honestly it just kinda... sucks. The controls aren't "tight" like others are saying, they're actually fairly clunky. Your first few steps build momentum before you hit normal speed which is just awkward in a game designed around platforming. It makes no sense. There are a bunch of upgrades to be found/bought, but most are completely useless and you end up using the same ones over and over as they're just more effective. The other games that come with the Treasure Trove are basically the same game but played as different characters. This is normally one of my favorite things with games like these but the other characters are just as clunky with their new mechanics. 

I don't understand the praise/hype around this game as there are a fair amount of other 8/16-bit styled games that are way better than whatever shovel Knight was trying to do. 114921082.review:
[h2]It Didn’t Click With Me. Not Recommended 5/10.[/h2]
[i][b]For Linux: [/b] Native.[/i]
[hr][/hr]
[h3]Summary[/h3]
I know this game has fans but in my opinion this game doesn’t elicit the kind of old school nostalgia feel the same classic action platform games of the past. It certainly has the look and the sound of a retro 8-bit game but old school action platform – such as Megaman, Contra, Ninja Gaiden and the like – has a flow to the game that Shovel Knight just does not have. In fact, Yacht Club went out of their way to make their game flow like rocks in your shoes. 

The level is designed with cheap deaths to stop you every step of the way instead of a having continuous motion and progress. Ever tried to run or jog 10 miles with rocks in your shoes, well, this is how it feels like in video game format. It is so annoying. 

On top of that, the controls are just sub-par compared to Shovel Knights contemporaries such as Celeste, Hollow Knight, Metroid Dread, Bloodstained Curse Of The Moon, and even remastered games such as Wonder Boy And The Dragon’s Trap has better controls. 

Is it all bad? No. Depending on your level of tolerance, you may find much enjoyment and you may click with this kind of gameplay. However, looking at the achievements, 76% of purchasers did not in fact finished the game which is an indication of a game with a lot of hype but does not have the substance to back it up. It is an indication that my assessment is more correct than not. 

Will you like this game. My bet is that you will not. Not recommended. 
[hr][/hr]
[h3]What’s Excellent[/h3]
[table]
[tr]
[td]1. Soundtrack is excellent.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]2. Graphics are colorful, vibrant and well animated.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]3. Narrative is simple but is well told. Cast of characters are memorable.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

It’s a shame really because Shovel Knight nailed a lot of things right. The music is top-notch chiptune; energetic, enthusiastic and thematically coherent. The graphics really nailed retro 8-bit in the best of sense; colorful, vibrant, detailed and immersive. The game even has a well-told story with a lively and memorable cast of characters. Everything is great except for the gameplay. 
[hr][/hr]
[h3]What’s Bad[/h3]

[table]
[tr]
[td]1. Controls are just subpar. The hit box and hit detection is way too small making platforming, jumping and evading more of a hindrance.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]2. Levels are designed with cheap deaths. It’s literally a case of players’ “Oh how did I not predict that ahead of time” design philosophy. Rather than challenging, the levels are cheesy. [/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]3. Combat is unfulfilling. It’s not terrible but it’s really just meh. Enemies are aggravating rather than challenging. [/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

As stated, the controls is just not good enough. [b]Simply not good enough.[/b] You will find that often you’re fighting against the controls during platforming to jump and land precisely where you want. This has to do with Shovel Knight accelerating way too fast from a standstill, and controlling SK in mid-air or when pogo-ing becomes unwieldy. This is in stark contrast to the really fine controls you get with games such as Celeste and Hollow Knight, where you can exactly move, stop, jump and land where you intend to. 

The levels too is just aggravating. In a platform sense, it’s not hard but it’s just filled with cheap deaths designed to get you because the player cannot predict what is going to happen next, such as falling down a level only to land on insta-kill floor which you won’t know it’s there unless you’ve been there before. This cheap level design is a way to mask the short and uninteresting level design for each stage. The levels are not there to challenge you, rather it’s there to halt your progress on purpose, slows down you playthrough to mask it’s lack of content. 

Combat too, is designed the same way. Combat in videogames is a dance. There is rhythm and motion and the combat in Shovel Knight is akin to an awkward white guy in a dance club. It has geeky, nerdy and jerky grooves and moves, almost laughable if it wasn’t so cringe to watch. It is not satisfying and feels unfulfilling. By the end of it, you don’t feel like a better gamer for finishing the game, rather you feel unsatisfied. 
[hr][/hr]
[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
I realize that Shovel Knight has fans. Hey, don’t let me stop you from enjoying the game if you like it. But for me, this ain’t it. Not by a long shot. 

If you want good action platformer, try Bloodstained Curse Of The Moon.

114599630.review:
TLDR; This is actually 4 great games in 1, and if you like retro-style games or platformers, it's worth the price.

First, it is important to make clear that this is actually 4 full length games in one package. Plus showdown. It is NOT a game with 3 DLCs included, or a game with 3 extra playable characters. It is 4 completely distinct games. And they're all great.

Shovel of Hope is a super solid retro platformer with some very clever mechanics and good level design, and a nice little story.

Plague of Shadows is set in mostly the same levels as Shovel of Hope, but with a completely different moveset, added secrets, a charming new story and characters, and some absolutely delightful subversions of the previous game.

Specter of Torment has completely new levels, some of which are especially fun, and a really flashy and satisfying movement system. Also a pretty good story.

King of Cards has shorter levels which allow it to add crazy and fun new mechanics, as well as a super fun movement system with a shoulder bash, which is consistently utilised in clever and creative ways. Also it has a (completely optional) strategy card game integrated into it, which is great fun to play.

If you're into platformers or retro-style games this is absolutely worth picking up. The price may seem steep, but it is also 4 games and they're all fantastic. If you think you'll like it, you almost certainly will.

113901039.review:
Intro
  If you are looking for a game focused on excellent combat, this is not the game you are looking for. When I bought this I was, and it turned out to be an excellent platformer. Make no mistake, the combat in this game is amazing, but it is mainly a platformer. Fortunately, I love platformers.

Bosses
  Bosses come at the end of every stage, and none were too difficult. Most of them I was able to beat first try. Furthermore, after a certain point in the game your character has so much health that you can trade hits with the boss and come out on top. Despite this, I found every boss fun to battle. Each boss is unique. No copy and paste bosses at all.

Platforming
  The bosses may be easy, but the platforming is very challenging.
  The amount of health you have does not make the platforming easier-- the main cause of death is falling off the map which kills you instantly. Besides missing a jump, enemies can easily knock you off the map (one is even designed to, and caused me more than my fair share of deaths). On later stages, checkpoints are further apart and enemies will quickly whittle down your health if you are not careful.
  As shovel knight, you have several moves you can use to get around. Of course you can walk (no sprinting), but you also can pogo off enemies and certain objects with your shovel. You gain more abilities as you play, including artifacts which give the player powerful attacks or utilities which consume magic.
  That is only shovel knight's moveset, which is tame in comparison to the others. The other characters you can play (further discussed in the next section) have many more abilities, like bomb jumps and slashing through a target to gain height, to name a couple.

Even more content
  The main part of the game you play as shovel knight. There are three more characters with completely different move sets you can play as: Plague Knight, Specter Knight, and King Knight. The first stages they play on are similar the same as the ones you play on as shovel knight. Later stages are completely different, though they use the same tilesets as the original levels.
  Besides the main game and bonus characters, there is a challenge mode that is unlocked after you beat the game in which you can play mini games, and a brawl mode where you can face your friends or the computer (the AI is not hard even at the highest difficulty) in a variety of different gamemodes.

Final thoughts
  The controls are precise. The pixel art is beautiful. The soundtrack is good. And I highly recommend this game.

If you notice anything wrong with this review (grammar, spelling, bad information) let me know.

Shovel Knight is one of those games that I've heard good things about, and trying it out I genuinely can't figure out why. Part of it is probably that I'm not old enough to remember some of the things it draws on nostalgia for, but I feel like the popularity of it has to come from more than that, and I just don't see why. It's got a couple of cool innovations like the player-chosen difficulty through letting you break checkpoints for a cash boost in exchange for losing more progress if you die, but in then end a game like Shovel Knight lives of dies on the moment-to-moment gameplay, and in my opinion the moment to moment gameplay of Shovel knight is awful. The character feels clumsy to control, challenges are poorly balanced, and most of the boss fights had cool enemy design but left me feeling more relief that I lucked out enough times to win than triumph that I actually mastered dealing with the boss.
Honestly, if anyone who liked the game wants to give an explanation as to why, I left comments allowed and I'd love to hear it because I just don't get it.

very good game with a very good team. different challenges and stories with different characters that feel meaningfully connected without being the same exact experience.

different rewards for doing more difficult decisions, rarely feels obligatory to try something. enemies have different skills that feel fun to dodge and attack around. hidden secret rooms are usually very interesting explorations of mechanics. collectibles range from useful tools to just fun secrets.

maps are all very interesting themes, they are of course the usual platformer levels of ice and water and air etc. but they give a very good feeling. music matches the looks matches the expectations very well. if absolutely nothing else i would recommend the music to most people.

the king knight card game is pretty unpopular, i enjoyed it thoroughly and it is optional in the confines of the playthrough. it is not like the rest of the game, it is much more lateral thinking in my opinion. 

smash bros-like gamemode adds different characters from the main story who all play very differently from one another. in general I really like everyone's abilities in the game, shovel knight (the character not the game....) is very straightforward but still manages to feel unique.

for platformers: very few of the jumps feel like pixel-perfect timing is required, and often rooms with jumps that are like that are immediately preceded by a checkpoint. feels very rhythmic.

i would recommend the game to anybody who likes platformers. i would also recommend it to somebody who likes feeling games. i would probably not recommend the game to people who people who like fast-paced games as only a few levels are noticeably quick paced.

112279659.review:
So, I have to be honest. I loved this game, I love the look, I love the music, I love the characters, and I love the stories, This is definitely one of these reviews that I wish Steam had a mixed review option like they have with Curator reviews giving options to have reviews be "informational" rather than just only positive and negative. I had a blast with Shovel Knight's campaign and I was enjoying myself up until I got up to Polar Knight. I feel that the game decides to start leaning more on cheap and instant kills rather than the fun platforming that was present early on.

Now to clarify there were some stages and areas in the early stages where you could just die by being knocked into a bottomless pit or dying by stepping on a spike or grazing it as you're jumping by, but Polar Knight is where you start to see it bumped up from maybe 15% of the stages and the like to about 75% of the map screens being you jumping over bottomless pits or navigating areas filled with spikes and not to mention. The stage itself is pretty fun, but once you get to the end you have to deal with Polar Knight shoveling out spike traps in a small arena and have to avoid them knocking you into it as it makes the arena you fight smaller and smaller. It does refresh it with snow after a while, but you have to basically speed through the fight to avoid being left on a small ledge or two to fight and avoid getting hit while you wait for the snow to refresh or just instantly die. Propeller Knight's fight has a similar aspect where the game ends up having him summon his ship which fires cannonballs which splits the stage into 3 different parts and trying to navigate the battle. 

I feel that Yacht Club Games even realized how bad it was for Shovel Of Hope as when you get to the last part of the game and you fight against all 8 bosses again you fight against Polar Knight first and while it still uses the spikes and everything that it did prior, Propeller Knight doesn't destroy the stage this time around and instead just drops bombs all over the stage to fight you with. That's not even mentioning the fight with the Enchantress's first phase being over a bottom less pit, but for Shovel Knight the fight is a lot easier then doing the fight as Plague Knight. I got through the fight and the campaign, but I'm fairly certain during my playthrough of SoH and Plague of Shadow (which I'll discuss in a second) I've died more from being knocked into a bottomless pit or into spikes then I ever did in any fight or any boss battle. 

For PoS there are a lot of problems I have, it's the same as SoH and I mean this as a compliment for the first part of the game where it's enjoyable and you are having a blast playing through the game with the new mechanics and gameplay features made the game so much fun, but then you get to Polar Knight and the same issue occurs. Heck, even elaborating over the mention of the fight in the last section my biggest problem is the final boss is much harder as the Plague Knight. As shovel Knight you can attack without having to worry about destroying the arena and you can do your best in navigating and fighting the Enchantress, but as Plague Knight,all your attacks basically destroy the arena and even using the Sentry Fuses would lead to either bombs that didn't hit a mark or them destroying a small amount of the stage which lead to me falling into a pit during the fight. I did the fight as Shovel Knight once and the same first phase as Plague Knight 9 times with 8 of the times that I died being because I was knocked into a bottomless pit. The only other problem I had was Phase 2 of the last boss being the same, but arena was constantly scrolling up with more room to blow up or navigate so it feels once again that YCG realized the mistake they made with balancing and decided to actually make the fight a an enjoyable challenge rather than it just being a fight where the challenge is hoping you don't get knocked into a bottomless pit.

There is one other thing that I do have to say for those who didn't buy Treasure Trove, I recommend picking it up over buying the standalone versions because despite me having a few issues with the campaigns, it is the only way to play/buy Plague of Shadows because despite it being years since the devs said they were going to make it a standalone release (or even just including it into SoH's campaign since it's the most expensive standalone entry) there is still no information about PoS being a standalone release as of March 2022.

I'm sure that Specter Knight and King Knight both have great campaigns, but after the frustration I experienced with both the last third of Shovel Knight and Plague Knight leaves a bad taste in my mouth and make it so I don't want to play the game any further as a result.

111236868.review:
Unfortunately, to my surprise, I have to post a negative review of this game. It has many amazing elements, interesting gameplay and enemies, but even after wanting to play it since it was released, playing it a bit some time later, so many years ago and finally finishing it recently, I can't pretend it didn't disappoint me. What have gone wrong?

[h1]Perfect atmosphere[/h1]
The game captured the old school platformers without a flaw. Not only with the simple mechanics, the same vibe of playing, especially with so many inspirations from [b]Rockman[/b] (Megaman) series, but also with artistic style, like game intros, retro graphics and other choices. But what made it so great, was also what makes this game so annoying.

[h1]Completionism[/h1]
I love games with things to collect. I always do 100% in the game, unless it's really unbalanced and unfair. Even if doing so is somewhat annoying. I did finish [b]Shovel of Hope[/b] with all collectibles, purchases etc. But that's one of the issue. After playing so many [i]metroidvanias[/i] I finally wanted some classic platformer experience, so I have chosen [strike]death[/strike] Shovel Knight, which I started long time ago, but never finished, because of frustration. But there's a problem.

[h1]Downsides[/h1]
My initial try of this game ended in a fiasco, because I couldn't bear how much You have to be perfect to not land in a hole. I could bear just that, but not that I felt cheated every time I died, because of those hard controls. I like characters that move freely, not like they were dragged by some kind of force. And every time I died I just lost [i]far too much monies[/i]. I can lose a progress and be backed to last checkpoint, but the amount of currency lost was too much. Just to Your knowledge. I played and love Dark Souls and I never felt cheated like I did in Shovel Knight. And I could always get my souls back, because of fair system that my bloodstains spawn in accessible area. It's not always the case in Shovel Knight. You could have 10k money, die 3 times and You can get below 5k of Your cash if You can't manage to get it back. And I have to mention one more thing. Some deaths were not fait at all. I dashed with one of my item, just to be pushed be suddenly spawned enemy and fell into the pit, before being able to get my money back. And because You lose 25% of Your cash, divided by 3 cash bags every time You die... You can imagine how quickly You can run out of money.

And here we are going to a point of why I hated the game. I mentioned I am completionist. So I had to get money to buy everything. It wasn't really a big deal. What was big deal was me burning out when collecting in-level collectibles (music sheets). I started to see a level not as a level I have to finish, but as an annoying secret wall I have to find, not die and get the sheet, and then finish the level. I stopped seeing levels as a levels. As a challenge. Instead it was just a way to the collectible. I didn't pay attention to the level, but to the breakable walls.

And at the end, some kind of challenges were just annoying. Not hard, but fakely hard. You needed meta knowledge, not skill, not agility, not fast reaction/thinking. I'm specifically saying about [spoiler]that pressing wall, that You have to time and find a safe place to not be squashed. But at one moment, I was confused as what to actually do. I thought I will be safe here. Nope. Dead. There? Dead again. And again and again and again. I was dying only because I didn't have a knowledge I couldn't have. And I had to react quickly or be squashed[/spoiler]. I am pretty good at platformers, so it's not that I complain, because game is too hard. Game wasn't really that hard. But some moments were like "we expect player to do something they can't expect to do, it will be fun". I didn't like it.

So despite they made artistic, visual, atmospheric part of the game perfectly, they didn't provide good gameplay. I didn't enjoy playing through the game, I just wanted to finish the game already, something I never feel while playing the game. Just to have it done. I even tried to play Plague Knight after finishing Shovel Knight's campaign, but after I died in pit, because I had (and still have) no idea how to do suepr precise bomb jump, I just quitted. I finished main campaign and couldn't start the next one, because of that. The controls of Plague Knight are so confusing, I don't really know where would I end up, after using his powers. So I didn't want to play the "guess game" with the controls.

Some people may enjoy the game, I didn't. I just share my issues, because someone may not like controls like that or severe punishments. The gameplay isn't fair and I can't just ignore that.

Easily the best modern interpretation of an old SNES game. I can tell it was heavily inspired by great classic games like Mega Man, Castlevania, and The Legend of Zelda; if this game was ported onto a old SNES Cartirdge I could believe it actually came out in the 90's. 

The story is simplistic yet fantastic. The levels get increasingly difficult and introduce new mechanics constantly, so no two levels feel alike. The themes of the bosses and their mechanics are perfectly suited to their stages. The music is absolutely amazing! My favorite track is "A Fateful Night" because it reminds me of old Runescape midi tracks which gives me huge nostalgia. Every component of this game was crafted to perfection, and I love it!

110673823.review:
Shovel Knight is a tribute to the NES days of videogames. It discards everything that didn't work like the cheap deaths and lives systems that send you back to the beginning of the game, while keeping everything that people loved about them such as the high difficulty, colorful characters, and catchy chiptunes. 

Our protagonist is a kind adventurer who's hesitant to fight, but WILL kick your ass if needed. Every boss has their own colorful personality, theme, and of course love being evil. 

The story is simple and is told through dialogue before boss fights. Shovel Knight's inner struggle is also depicted through playable dream sequences, which is a clever way to include a touching story into a silly platform game. The ending is also a total tear jerker. 

The spikes and bottomless pits are one hit kills and there's a LOT of them throughout the game, and you'll mostly die from them instead of running out of health. A lot of tight platforming jumps. This is what gives the game its "NES-hard" feel. It can be frustrating at times, but that's also what makes the game extremely rewarding to complete. 

The boss fights are easily my favorite part of the game. They challenge your skill and each is a big puzzle to be solved. They will constantly kill you and force you to get better.

110028145.review:
Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove is an incredible old school style Adventure, platformer with a lot to love. So it’s now time for the story. In the land of Pridemoor it was wild and free, where legendary adventurers would face monsters to protect the people and no two knights were more famous than Shovel Knight and his trusty companion Shield night.

The two were an inseparable pair, but that all changed when the Tower of Fate opened up, sensing great danger from its opening Shovel Knight and Shield Knight went to investigate. Unfortunately Shield Knight was lost and Shovel Knight barely escaped the Tower of Fate with his life.

Heartbroken he went into solitude only to hear tales of evil knights called The Order of No Quarter led by the mysterious and evil leader the enchantress. Now Shovel Knight must raise his mighty shovel against the new evil. But unknown to everyone the order is not as united as they think, the Crafty and tricky Plague Knight has a plan to get the essence of each member of the order of No Quarter as well as the enchantress in order to gain ultimate power and to gain the courage for love.

But before all that how did this all start, how did the order come together and who is the enchantress? Well Specter Knight the first member of the order is tasked by the enchantress to gather each of the evil knights in order to make a powerful and invincible order, Specter Knight complies having no choice but to obey the enchantress, but in the dark Fortress he laments on how it all went wrong in his life. With that going on, a crazy new pastime has taken up residence in the land, a card game called Joustus and a tournament is taking place the winner will be crowned King Of Cards and that title alone is interesting to one particular person the one and only King knight whose desires to be king will test him as he tries to claim what he desires no matter the cost.

All right let's talk about what's to like about the games, the gameplay for each of the games is fun, frustrating and tight. Shovel Knight’s gameplay is good as you use your shovel as not just as a weapon, but as a way to traverse the environment, Plague Knight’s gameplay is good it can be a bit tricky at times, but it has a nice variety of different bombs and power ups to use. Specter Knight’s gameplay is extremely fun definitely has a nice ninja vibe to it, King Knight’s gameplay like Plague Knight is a bit tricky but there are some nice power ups to use. The gameplay definitely has a nice variety. 

The platforming in the game is very good, definitely tight with   different ways to play in not just the main game, but in the three other games. The power ups in the game are very good each one with their own unique look and purpose that can help you to traverse certain difficulty levels.

The pixel graphics/arts style is very good nicely detailed with plenty of great locations to look at, the levels in the game are very good, nice and varied with plenty of interesting locations also if you think you know a level because you beat it in Shovel Knight, well how you play the level and traverse it is quite different in plague Knight or the other two games.
The enemy and boss designs are very good, especially the bosses each one with their own unique look and feel. 

The enemies and bosses are also pretty fun to fight, some of the enemies having their own unique powers specific for that level, while the bosses has their own unique powers and ways to beat you if you're not careful. The music in the game is very good each level has its own unique tract and you'll be hard-pressed to find one that you don't love.

The stories in each of the games are really good, Shovel Knight is quite simple, but has some nice surprises and some heartfelt moments in it.  Plague Knight’s story is probably the most adorable and heartfelt having you watch him try to get the courage to ask the one he loves out it also has a good moral message.

Specter Knight is a good prequel story that shows how everything transpired; it definitely has a nice tragic feel to it and has good themes in it like heroism. King Knight’s story is really good, it has a great Shakespearean tragedy to it.The characters in the game are very good especially the side characters and especially in the three other games like plague Knight, Specter Knight and King Knight’s story.

The Comedy of the game is okay nothing really laugh out loud but enjoyable nonetheless, the game also has plenty of nice references to other games like Megaman. Shovel Knight Showdown is a great versus game that lets you play with different characters, bosses and some enemy types you have seen in the game.

All right let's talk about what's to dislike, there are just a little bits that can be a pain, like certain levels can be a real pain and feel a bit cheap like propeller Knight’s level.

I also didn't like the mini game Joustus that was in King Knight’s game, I don't know it was very frustrating and I feel it was a bit unneeded, like you could have told King Knight’s story without needing the card game gimmick.

All right then with that finished Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove is an incredible old school style Adventure, platformer with a lot to love, from the really good stories, the fun, frustrating and tight gameplay and very good pixel graphics/arts style. The whole game is just a great, great example on how to capture the feel and look of classic games, so I highly, highly recommend this game.

110019331.review:
If you have EVER played a 2d retro platformer, then this is the game Collection you didn't know you needed. This is one of my all-time favorite Steam games, and for very good reason. It plays like any of your favorite retros, and expands upon them in fun ways.

Shovel Of Hope:
Shovel of Hope is a really good introduction to the story, and the gameplay. Your adventuring buddy, Shield Knight has been taken by The Enchantress, and it is your duty to save Shield Knight from her. In order to get to her, you must defeat all of "The Order of No Quarter." This game has fun mechanics, like bouncing of the enemies head, charging up for a super slash, or using mana to use relics. The relics all have different uses, like a barrage of attacks with the Dust Knuckles, eliminating every enemy at once with the blow of the War Horn, or soaring through the air, slicing through enemies with an awesome propeller called the Propeller Dagger. In every game you also get special armors that can give you interesting effects.

Plague of Shadows:
In Plague of Shadows, you have the same levels from before, but you have a completely different way to play them. You have even more customization options, that change the way you play. You can choose a different bomb set to best fit your play style. As the evil Plague Knight, you wish to obtain a potion to become immortal. In "order" to do this, you must defeat, "The Order of No Quarter" that you are a part of. You also get a bunch of different relic-type weapons, called Arcana. While this game is fun, it is definitely the worst one you can get. After playing Shovel of Hope, it feels like the same thing, but worse. There is customization, but the customization only slightly alters moves, and the moveset doesn't match with the level design, since it was made for Shovel of Hope. If you only plan one, DO NOT choose this one. You will think the rest of the games are as bad, without giving those treasure troves a proper chance. This game takes place in the same time as Shovel of Hope.

Specter of Torment:
A dark, stormy night, a mysterious figure, and a tragic backstory are all a part of my favorite Shovel Knight game. Specter of Torment does everything right. Like in the previous entries, you platform through levels, defeating "The Order of No Quarter." We start off knowing almost nothing of our "hero," Specter Knight. Throughout the levels, we learn more and more of his tragic backstory. That's another thing different, the levels are all accessible from the beginning, and you can choose any level, at any time. You get to slash your scythe through enemies, use the Curios, to inflict critical damage, and fly through the air with a quick slash. You even get to ride on rails like a skateboard, and you're Tony Hawk! The Curios are the Relics of the game including a healing item, a powerful claw attack, a time slowing device, a cloning mirror, and a skeleton minion. Not to mention the fact that all of the Curios can be upgraded to be EVEN BETTER. This prequel is so much fun, and my personal favorite with it's fun mechanics.

King of Cards:
Play as King Knight, the self proclaimed ruler, as he traverses through an incredible amount of levels. In King of Cards, there are more changes that can be definitely be called improvements. King knight uses his heavy armor to bash into enemies. After bashing, you bounce into the air, spinning. This can be used to bounce through levels using it's interesting mechanics. The story is about King Knight wanting to be the best at a card game called Joustus That's it. It's that simple. The Relics this time are called heirlooms, and they are a lot of fun. A flaming sword you fling around your body multiple times, float in a bubble with a frog, and get this, boots that make you turn into a tornado! This game is the second best in my opinion, because they learned what needed to be improved more and more. I admit it is more fun then Specter of Torment overall. By the time they got to this game, they learned everything that needed fixing. I'd say this game is flawless. It is good in every way as long as you like this type of game.

Showdown:
Use many different characters previously unplayable to defeat everyone else. Showdown is basically Super Smash Bros, but with Shovel Knight Characters. You get to select rules, stages, characters and their colors, and game modes to dominate the battlefield. There are achievements and a story mode. FOR EVERY CHARACTER. The game is fun, but it just can't compete with the glorious other games.

109768163.review:
A great take on the classic MegaMan-style "8 bosses building up to final boss" action platformer combined with a world progression/map and RPG-like growth mechanics.
* Shovel of Hope is the pretty classic styled action-platformer with simple yet effective power-up options
* Plague of Shadows goes a more "short range" system with throwing or placement mechanics instead, forcing slightly more strategic approach to stages
* Spectre of Torment is a harder game with more intricate movement options, but with effective resource management ends up a much more fluid experience
* King of Cards combines a simpler/more straightforward platformer split into considerably more (but shorter) stages (with fewer bosses more spread out) with a neat card battle mini-game
* Showdown's a nice simple fighter

There's plenty of extra optional challenges mixed in, of varying difficulty.

Some aspects can be a little annoying - there's a few movement options you get throughout the game that would be nice to have earlier for example.
The artstyle, too, can be a bit hard on the eyes in a few places due to entire rooms having large animated effects. But otherwise, the artstyle is very consistent and portrays exactly what it needs to (but not more).
The music is excellent and easily one of the highlights of the game.

108830826.review: Shovel Knight is a retro inspired 2D Platformer where you play as Shovel Knight in his quest to rescue Shield Knight. The game has near perfect level design and progression that teaches the player new tricks as the game progresses. By the end of the game you'll be layering the lessons learned to get through some fairly challenging, but certainly not impossible platforming sections and boss fights. There were only a few moments where I thought the game may be a tad unfair, but those moments are few and far between. The music in top notch and always kept me wanting to give a section or boss fight another go. Shovel Knight encourages players to look for secrets by having a upgrade system where you can increase your health and mana. You also may find challenge rooms where the reward is a special magic ability. These abilities while not required certainly help in later areas. I'm writing this review having beaten the base campaign as Shovel Knight, but there are also three more distinctly different playthroughs where you play as boss characters, with each of them having their own style of play. I plan on coming back to those knights later, but the base game alone is worth a strong recommendation.

108743703.review:
[h1] Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove [/h1]

[b] A Treasure To Play [/b]

A legendary collection of one of the greatest platforming series ever made, [b] Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove [/b] provides memorable, engaging gameplay for a discounted price. Here's a breakdown of my thoughts of each game, followed by a rating for the collection!

[h2] Shovel of Hope [/h2]

The OG adventure was fantastic! I enjoyed the colorfully organized pixel art, the simple yet difficult gameplay, and the amazing soundtrack. However, the final levels were a bit frustrating and I wished that some characters were fleshed out more. I liked that there was a varied customization within this game without it feeling overwhelming. There are shovel upgrades and different types of armor to purchase as well as health/mana upgrades. Additionally, there is a number of collectibles, and many weren’t too hard to find. Collectible hunting didn’t feel like a chore nor felt like I was going too far out of my way to break game flow!

The story is good but lacks some depth. I wish some characters had more personality, and the level designs could have been crafted in a way where it gave some insight to their backstories rather than an overall theme. However, the themes were great! I also really loved the soundtrack, with it being one of the best I have heard in gaming! There are some serious jams in here and they fit a lot of the fights that occur.

Overall, this first entry is delightful. It has a few flaws that kept it from being “next level” for me, but it is a finely crafted platformer with a whole lot of charm. I can easily [b] Recommend [/b] this entry, and it left me excited to see what’s next in store with…

[h3] Final Verdict: 9/10 (Excellent) [/h3]

[h2] Plague of Shadows [/h2]

The first expansion was a disappointment. A slew of bombs, boosts, and abilities are introduced to the player, and Plague Knight plays very differently from Shovel Knight himself. However, I felt that this overcomplicated things, and along with the reuse of all the OG levels, led to a more frustrating experience at times rather than rewarding. I did like the large offering of abilities for "PK", but I felt that I rarely used many. There are some types of bombs and boosts that are more effective in some levels or against certain bosses, but I never felt a desire to play around with them. The armor sets are also reused from the OG, except now with "PK's" theme. I also was disappointed that there weren’t many new stages for "PK", which sucks because some older stages failed to fit with his playstyle. Instead, he feels sort of shoved into the OG with a new story. The story was nice, focusing on "PK" and his partner Mona as they figure out a way to prove to the world that they are great alchemists. There is still the trademark humor, and some more depth is given to many characters. This addition was great and gave me more of what I enjoyed in the OG.

Overall, this entry was just “good”. I felt that there were some missteps that led to a more underwhelming experience than I had hoped to have. "PK" takes some getting used to, and I wasn’t really a fan of the mixture of projectile weaponry and jump boosts being a dominant focus. I can still [b] Recommend [/b] it, but I much prefer the OG and its streamlined design.

[h3] Final Verdict: 7/10 (Good) [/h3]

[h2] Specter of Torment [/h2]

The second expansion turned out to be a delightful resurgence to the quality of the OG. The player takes control of Specter Knight in a prequel to the OG, and there is a lot more emphasis on storytelling and level redesign. I liked the return to melee combat, as well as a new form of traversal. "SK" can dash into foes mid-air, allowing for chain attacks to kill multiple enemies or scale certain obstacles. The timing of these jumps was tricky, but they became fluid enough in time. In addition, there's the ability to scale walls for a short time as well as to wall jump. This made for some cool acrobatic segments, and there were only a handful of times where mechanics seemed to frustrate me.

The level design does what I wished [b] PoS [/b] would have done - revamp the OG levels to suit the new character. Some were changed for "SK" to move around easier, and it was a great choice. Besides that, the enemies and bosses are a bit samey, with a few new changes. The best part of this game is the way characters are fleshed out. While "PK" is given a bit more character in “PoS”, his humor and quirkiness didn’t quite hit the same tone as "SK". There's an emotional story here that both the OG and first expansion sorely lack, and it helps make "SK" a unique character. Other than that, there's a new set of upgrades, armors, and set of collectible items. The weapon upgrades were more useful here than in [b] PoS [/b] and did not feel as redundant. The music is still mostly just remixed stuff from the base game, but it's still solid despite being less memorable.

Overall, [b] SoT [/b] was a great bounce back that reached the same level of quality as the OG. There is a nice character redesign, cool tweaks, and a great story here! I can easily [b] Recommend [/b] this expansion if the idea of mid-air attack dashes and wall-climbing sound like cool additions!

[h3] Final Verdict: 9/10 (Excellent) [/h3]

[h2] King of Cards [/h2]

Arguably one of the best send-offs any series could ask for, the third expansion manages to bring together nearly all the beloved cast, forward thinking platforming, and charm the series had built up prior to its release - all while adding in a solid card game. King Knight gets his time to shine in a wacky adventure where he attempts to become ruler of all the lands, and many antics ensue. Gameplay here is very brute force compared to other entries - "SK" was floaty and bouncy, "PK" was reserved and tactical, and "SK" was flashy and dexterous. "KK’s" focus is using his strength to bash into enemies in the most flamboyant of ways, and it showcases an interesting dynamic of his character in the process - he’s equally capable of showcasing strength yet can quiver in fear and become a momma’s boy at any moment. The gameplay supports his character, which is tricky to perfect in a single title alone, but Yacht Club has proven this time and again. The card game introduced is not perfect, but it's a nice change of pace and adds a rich layer of content. I also enjoyed the smaller but more numerous levels, as it kept the platforming diversity high in the process.

Overall, [b] KoC [/b] is one of the best finales I have ever played and showcases so much of what Yacht Club has learned. I can easily [b] Recommend [/b] it to any platformer fan or card-game fan looking for a fun and humorous adventure!

[h3] Final Verdict: 9/10 (Excellent) [/h3]

[h2] Showdown [/h2]

The “meh” entry for me, which is fine because it is sort of an “extra”. It's a fighting game combining various characters and stages throughout the series, and it takes some elements from famous fighting games to provide a decent package.

Overall, the presentation is neat, and the controls are solid, but it's not very compelling. It’s a nice addition but I wouldn’t buy it outside of [b] Treasure Trove [/b]. I would [b] Not Recommend [/b] it unless you’re a huge fighting game fan and would like to see these characters duke it out with various customization options and unlockables…

[h3] Final Verdict: 5/10 (Average) [/h3]

Overall, this collection is an absolute steal and easily one of the best money can buy. You owe it to yourself to check out this series, as it's a refreshing look into the platforming genre which oozes with humor, charm, and love throughout! I can easily [b] Recommend [/b] it as it's one of the best platforming series around!

[h2] Overall Final Verdict: 10/10 [/h2]

If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my curator page for my thoughts on a variety of other games!

https://store.steampowered.com/curator/37542043-ADHD-Reviews/

108546454.review:
A couple years ago, I made my own list of "top 10 best games released between 2010 and 2019."  Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove was #3.  Here was what I wrote to explain why:



Shovel Knight is another game I heard about years before I played it.  The titular character's blue armor, horned helmet, and curious choice of weapon popped up all over the place.  Just the idea of a video game about a knight on a platforming adventure who uses a shovel as both a weapon and a tool sounds like something straight out of the good old NES days.

Of course, if you want a short summary of why Shovel Knight is so good, just spare a minute and a half to watch this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ktCH_zpEMN4 .  He says it better, and catchier, than I can.

It didn't take long for me to say that everything about this game is as good as Brentalfloss says.  I'd go so far as to call Shovel Knight "the next Cave Story" with how classic, good and influential it is and how it channels the greatness of so many other great games while still having its own identity.  This is a game that feels like it was made by people who grew up loving video games and they wanted to bring back and revitalize their favorites.  I can't think of a single bad thing about it.

By the time I started playing in late 2016, it had gotten its first expansion, Plague of Shadows, so I moved on to that when I was done with the baseline game (or "Shovel of Hope" as it's now called).  Shovel of Hope already set new standards in indie gaming, but Plague of Shadows defines what DLC should be: Adding good things to the base game while also doing its own thing (the fact that it was free if you already owned Shovel Knight is pretty nice too, but I'd have paid money for it).  Getting used to the new gameplay took some time (Plague Knight is practically made for speedrunners, one of which I am not), and from reading comments elsewhere I can tell I'm not the only one with that opinion, but it's not for nothing they usually say that "it's worth it."  The only unfortunate thing about PoS is its acronym, because, pun intended given the alchemical expertise of its protagonist, Plague of Shadows mixes up Shovel of Hope's already winning formula and creates gold from it.

About half a year after I finished PoS, the next DLC came out, and when I call Specter of Torment "DLC" I mean it's more like a full-on sequel.  All the stages, bosses and music are remixed (and the series so far already had great music, but I just love these remixes).  Specter Knight's mobility gimmicks are easier to get a handle on than Plague Knight's while still being fun to use, and I like his items and upgrades more than Shovel Knight's.  It was even more replayable than the first two thanks to New Game+ mode revamping the gameplay in a big way.  Playing a prequel so I could see how the events of these games got started was also some nice perspective, especially seeing it from the point of view of someone on the bad guys' side even if I now think of Specter Knight as more of a tragic hero than a villain (or at least, as an "he's not clear-cut good or evil" character).  The story in general has a darker tone while still retaining a lot of color and humor.  I already expected something fantastic, but Yacht Club gave me more than that; they managed to top themselves and make something even better than the first two games.

It's also cool that SoT was released with an option to genderswap the main characters in Shovel of Hope, which got me to play it again not only to re-sharpen my platforming skills but also to see what everyone looked like.

Finally, after some delays, at the end of the decade came the final DLC, this time about who was generally considered the weakest of the bad guys (but he was tougher in SoT), enough so that he was more of a practice boss than anything else: King Knight.  I already liked the idea of "the most disposable bad guy gets to be a main character," especially with how high my standards for Shovel Knight were by then.  It's got everything the other games have: Great graphics, sound (especially since it uses both Shovel of Hope and Specter of Torment's tunes), characters and gameplay.  Like Specter of Torment, it's a prequel that does a good job of setting up the main game, and also like all the other expansions, I appreciate how it takes some previously inconsequential (if still likeable) characters and gives them bigger roles.

Worthy of its own section is King of Cards' game-spanning Joustus sidequest/minigame.  When it comes to card games, I tend to either be good or suck at them and to either love or not care for them.  After more initial failures than I have any excuse for, I gave up on it for the rest of my first time through the game, and then I took it more seriously when I went back to do achievement hunting.  It helps that by then I had much better cards and had more room to make (and learn from) mistakes when playing earlier opponents...and gave myself permission to use cheat cards.  Yeah, you can buy ways to cheat at Joustus, and don't feel bad for doing so, at least until you're ready to try to earn the "become Joustus champion without buying cheats or cards" achievement.  While Joustus didn't interest me at first, the more I played the more I liked it.  It's a real solid game in and of itself, not like some other card game-related sidequests from other video games (and I know we can all think of at least one).  The rules and strategies are easy to learn with some practice, I liked seeing the themed decks all these characters I've come to love use (not to mention seeing those characters as collectible cards), and lots of new mechanics are introduced as you progress through the game to keep things fresh throughout.  If that's not enough, there's an optional boss fight unlocked from the Joustus sidequest, and it's easily the toughest boss in the series...and when you love a game so much that you want to complete everything it has to offer, Joustus just adds that much more fun and satisfaction to make it all even more worth it.  Joustus warrants plenty of play time on its own, both for the rewards and just for fun, and that's the mark of a great game.

Of course, KoC wasn't the only thing released at the end of the year.  Also released was the "if I can't be playable in Smash Bros., I'll make my own" Shovel Knight Showdown.  Much like Smash, it's a great way to wrap things from across the series in one game while still adding new things, especially being able to play as characters we previously couldn't, even if they won't get their own DLCs.  The characters' story modes add some more insight into their motivations and actions in their respective games, even main characters like Shovel Knight himself and a couple of regular enemies that were previously just faceless baddies with no personality beyond a line or two of dialogue in Specter of  Torment, and being able to play as so many characters is a huge treat for fans of the series.  There are only two game modes (three if you include Targets, which can be its whole other level of challenge), but there's a ton of variety in the variant rules those modes can have.

Really, what I said about Shovel of Hope applies to the entire series: It combines the best things about so many games while still having its own identity, it's pure classic, and I can't really think of anything bad to say about it.  How much do I love it?  Shovel of Hope and Plague of Shadows were, if you take them as a combined game (since I played them back to back and SoT hadn't been released yet), only the second game that has achievements for which I've gotten all of them, and I've done the same with Specter of Torment, King of Cards, and Showdown.

I've gotten a lot of, "Thank you for playing!" messages in the credits in my time, but rarely have I said, "You're welcome," and meant it as much as I do to your special thank-you message in Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove.

108371597.review:
is this the best retro/pixel platform game of the decade?? Shovel Knight alone might have been, but especially now that the Specter Knight, King Knight, and Plague Knight games are available... it's pretty hard to argue. Very tight controls, pitch-perfect sound, and the kind of attention to design detail that sets it solidly among god-tier games like Hollow Knight or Cup Head - this is a phenomenal game. A tour de force!

It's also a difficult game. It can be incredibly frustrating, I'm talking like Super Meat Boy, Dark Souls, "Oh my god I am about to throw my controller across the room" levels of rage. If you're not a completionist you can avoid the worst of it, but there will definitely be times where you will land on instakill spikes over and over and over and over again, until all the money you've collected has been decimated, and you feel like you're going to crack if you see those stupid bags of gold with their stupid flappy wings pop out of your stupid dead body one more time...

Plague Knight's quest is the weakest gameplay of the four, in my opinion, but I would heartily recommend playing each and every one of the 4!!! classic platformer games included in the Shovel Knight pantheon. I have no idea what kind of dark magic Yacht had to employ to create this masterpiece but I hope they've got plans to perform another similar ritual in the future, because the genre is starving for mastercraft content like this.

107867598.review:
[h1]Across all games[/h1]

[b]Positives[/b]

+ Perfectly captures that retro feel in terms of design and sound.
+ Music is great with several really memorable tracks in particular.
+ Controls are tight and well-tuned.
+ Great characters that quickly establish themselves without needing tons of backstory.
+ Tons of content - 4 different stories which play differently and a versus style mode.
+ Lots of optional collectables which provide mini-challenges to acquire.
+ Good risk vs reward when you die as 3 money bags will spread out from where you died which you can then go back and try to recover.

[b]Negatives[/b]

- There are times when the money bags that appear after your death are in places you’ll never reach.
- A few too many deaths caused by something knocking you into lava / spikes / bottomless pit for an insta-death.

[h1]Shovel of Hope[/h1]

[b]Positives[/b]

+ Great level design.
+ Great bosses.
+ Using the shovel to bounce off of things is lots of fun.
+ Lots of gadgets at your disposal.

[b]Negatives[/b]

- In some of the more finicky platforming sections if you get hit by something you’ll be knocked off into a bottomless pit with no means to react or recover which can be frustrating.
- In some boss fights you can feel a bit dependent on the Phase Locket (makes you briefly invulnerable) due to Shovel Knight’s lack of maneuverability options, or you can use it to cheese bosses (with max magic it can be spammed a lot).

[h1]Plague of Shadows[/h1]
[b]Positives[/b]

+ You can make modifications to the properties of both your thrown and jump bombs, allowing you to mix things up and experiment with different approaches.
+ Plague Knight has a load of gadgets at his disposal and controls quite wildly.
+ Much better means of recovery if you get knocked off compared to Shovel Knight due to double jump and the ability to create temporary platforms underneath.
+ Has a really distinctively wild feel due to the controls which matches well with the character and can be lots of fun.

[b]Negatives[/b]

- There are tweaks to sections of the levels to fit Plague Knight, but they’re largely the same levels as Shovel of Hope’s.
- You’re fighting the same bosses outside of a couple of new ones.
- Some of the later stages don’t feel particularly fun as Plague Knight because they require more fine-tuned jumping which don’t necessarily meld well with his fast and loose playstyle. Tailor-made levels for him would have been a home run.

[h1]Specter of Torment[/h1]

[b]Positives[/b]

+ Specter Knight's abilities to wall-climb, dash through objects and enemies, and rail-grind are arguably the most fun parts across all of the games.
+ Great new levels purpose-built for him and his new abilities.
+ The remixed bosses play great and are arguably better than the originals.
+ Can still be knocked to his death as per Shovel Knight but has an ability which allows his mana bar to take a big hit to avoid instant death which makes it a little less harsh.
+ The most fully realised, lean story game of the four.

[h1]King of Cards[/h1]

[b]Positives[/b]

+ Joustus is a fun puzzle card game which isn’t too complicated while still having some depth.
+ Fun to build up a collection of cards and build the best deck.
+ Not as fun to control as Specter Knight, but still has unique controls and abilities combined with tailor-made levels.
+ Great new levels which explore more of the world.
+ Makes full use of the rich world it has built up to fully enjoy itself in a fun and easy-going plot.

[h1]Showdown[/h1]

[b]Positives[/b]

+ Lots of stages to play on.
+ Lots of characters to play as and unlock, all faithful to the original game.
+ Can be good fun with some friends playing locally.

[b]Negatives[/b]

- Characters don’t have that many moves and it’s not particularly deep.
- No online multiplayer.

[b]Conclusion[/b]

I would rank them: Specter > King > Shovel > Plague > Showdown

Overall this is a fantastic package of games, all of which I would recommend. There’s a fun world to explore here and if you have even a slight retro itch then this will scratch it. That being said, this game isn’t good just because of its obvious retro style - it’s a very well-made 2D platformer regardless and fully-realised. An instant classic, I hope we get to see more of Shovel Knight and the world this game has built.

107823316.review:
I really want to like this, but I don't. I understand that the instant death pits and spikes and what not are meant to be a "Nintendo hard" kind of learning and I totally understand that. This is far from the hardest game I've played and I'm sure I could beat it if put the effort in, I am not at all saying that it should be easier, but the way you lose money to cheap deaths just drives me berserk.

Bear in mind that the game throws cash at you, it's not scarce: you don't need to worry about the money, but taking it away from me is just insanely irritating. I would enjoy the game 100% more if I could just ignore the money and not worry about losing it, but I know myself well enough to know that I can't.

I know it's silly, I know that I'm probably denying myself the enjoyment of the rest of the game, but more often than not, Shovel Knight leaves me feeling annoyed and that's not what I want out of my game time.

I wanted to like this, I understand why many people do like it, but I don't and therefore I can't recommend it.

106421022.review:
Disclaimer: I've only beaten the base game, and got half way through the Plague DLC before giving up.

I've read so many good things about Shovel Knight. Some would even go as far as calling the game "ground-breaking". I also read that that the base game and the Plague DLC are the worst part of the series, that I'll never be able to know.
I can see it has 96% positive reviews which astonishes me.

First off, i'd like to start and say: there's nothing inherently wrong with SK. It's a platformer. It has a lot of charm, soundtrack is a mixed bag, but it has some very good tracks nonetheless, gameplay is also a mixed bag. You have some abilities that are completly broken, and some you wont ever use... because they suck. The combat system is extremly limited too.

At any rate, you have dozens of hours of gameplay in front of you if you enjoy the game, so it's a good investment. Story is non-existent.

My problem lies in the fact that the game goes too far in the platforming aspect. I've played Celeste, 100% the game, so I dont mean it's hard. I mean it's tedious. It's boring. It's repetitive. There's also quite a few bullshit section that are die and retry. Find the perfect path, the perfect jump. Some think it's what makes a platformer interesting, and I'd agree. But the game failed to charm me enough to make me want to push through those sections

In my opinion, there isnt a single groundbreaking thing in Shovel Knight.
It's Megaman with a shovel. Simple as that.

I may come back to the game in a few years, to try again and play the other characters.

I wish there was a "mixed review" button but since there isnt, i'll give it a "not recommended".
If you expect something new from Shovel Knight, you will be disapointed.
It's a game that could have been released 30 years ago, and no one would have batted an eye.
Shovel Knight is a "meh" kind of game.
Fuck ladders btw

106273233.review:
Regardless of the knight, levels offer abundant variety, every area furnishing its own twist. But unlike some games, which require the player to perform a new technique before abandoning it in future levels, Shovel Knight incorporates each skill, building on past experiences. Each level includes multiple checkpoints, saving the player's progress.

Levels seemed as if they were made just difficult enough to challenge the player, while allowing them to succeed on the first, or second attempt. Die once, learn from it, and don't die again.

The precise, detailed, complex, and diverse gameplay of Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove is backed by retro style music, and visuals which are clear, and oddly cute.

The final innovation of Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove is the differentiation of the four campaigns. They share themes, mechanics, aesthetics, collectibles, and ideas, but alter, tweak, and adjust them for divergent results. 

Simultaneous with King of Cards, Yacht Club Games released Showdown (all of which is included in the Treasure Trove).Showdown includes two game modes; a four person melee, and a short story mode for one or two players. In the story mode the player chooses one of eight starting characters. Each character has their own story. The story mode requires the player to win seven matches, destroy targets in an arena, and fight the final boss. Four scenes relevant to the character are interspersed after matches.

Hour and a half of gameplay and I think I've seen all that needs to be seen already.

I find the amount of effort given to this game quite wonderful in the art style, the music, and the way the whole setting was handled.

However the gameplay, it takes a lot from very OLD platformers in just about every single way which can be a good thing for some people who are looking for something to take them back to nostalgia days. For newer players it neglects. The controls and platforming challenges are something straight out of platformers from the distant past which is quite bad since you'll be fighting the controls to do basic functions of your character at an inopportune times. It feels like you're playing on ice, you can feel a gradual momentum which can throw off precise platforming you're expected to do very early on in the game. They also throw in a ton of instant kill traps and pits which are used far too often than they have to be making it feel like being in a blind playthrough is entirely the player's fault for going in without knowing they're going to get blasted into a pit by something that gives very little reaction time to notice.

I really want to like this game, but it has been getting frustrating a little too quickly so be weary of these challenges, I of course have not seen even most of the game but if this is beginning is what I am to expect for other parts of the game then I think I'm just fine not playing more.
