98332930.review:
Steam Review: Shovel Knight Treasure Trove

TL;DR(Average across all games)-
Gameplay: 9/10
Story & Characters: 7/10
Writing & Dialogue: 7/10
Graphics: 10/10
Music & Sound Design: 10/10
Length: 5/10
Replayability: 7/10
The joy of playing a video game made of only the best parts of past video games, along with the realization that future developers may never catch on to the idea: Once in a lifetime/10

-REVIEW-

I’m going to be honest; I seriously didn’t have much faith in the original Shovel Knight title, and I regret having those feelings to this day. I remember looking at the game and thinking, “wait, a knight that has a shovel? That sounds lame, how’s that going to work?”

Oh me of little faith, and how I felt it! As I watched youtubers gush over how great the game was, with Quarter Guy being particularly outspoken, I decided, eff it, I’ll give it a shot. I fell in love with the game after just a few levels, and quickly realized that indie games still have a lot to offer the industry, even if they take on an 8-bit appearance. Now what was once a great game is now a phenomenal treasure trove of games, and I’m amped to see what else Yacht Club can come up with.

With five whole games to talk about, let me go from what I feel are my least to most favorite in that order. Shovel Knight Showdown is technically at the bottom, but that doesn’t mean it’s a bad title, far from it. It’s a blast to have a title that lets you play pretty much any knight, or any character you want, and I enjoyed checking out all of them. My only real issue is, if you’ve played Super Smash Bros., Showdown doesn’t have a whole lot else to offer, aside from some story bits. Still, if you’re into the more competitive side of gaming, give this title a try!

Shovel Knight: Plague of Shadows comes next, and I was stoked that Plague Knight was one of the three knights selected for extra titles. As a game, I found the story to be quite heartwarming and even rather surprising; love comes in all shapes and sizes, after all. I think out of all of the games, Plague Knight’s set of powers are, to me, the most varied, from unleashing various explosions to summoning purple liquid vats to use as platforms or detonate for damage, among others. The reason I rate this the lowest of the four is simply because I felt like I was jumping in and out of the menu rather frequently, as there were lots of ways to manipulate the basic attack, and certain factors were better in some situations and worse in others; it made the game feel a bit slower than I liked. Still, it was a very fun title that put a clever spin on the not-too-often-used villainous protagonist formula.

King of Cards comes next, and man, that one made me laugh. Nothing adds life to an already decadent dandy by painting him as an immature momma’s boy who wants to be all powerful and amazing and such. The addition of a card based minigame was a clever way to add a new feature to the title, although I was thankful that it was entirely optional, as I wasn’t very good at it. The decision to make levels more numerous and shorter was a nice touch as well. I never had any issues with the longer levels in the other games, but I liked how they made this game stand out as well. The fact that, to me, King Knight had one of the more difficult control styles was my only real complaint with the game, and even then it wasn’t terrible.

For my second place, the original Shovel of Hope takes the cake. I was aware of most of the best parts of classic NES games put into the title, and yet even I had no idea how a common attack style from Duck Tales would be so fun to do! This one feels the most well-balanced in terms of gameplay and is a satisfying title to get to, and as such not really having anything to stand out with other than being Shovel Knight is the only negative thought I have about it. Suffice to say, it isn’t my number one favorite, but it’s easy to see how a game with such a simple idea that took successful pages from past classics could go on to become such a monumental triumph in the indie circle.

Finally, Spectre of Torment, or as I’ve heard it to be called, the speedrunner’s favorite of the franchise. What I enjoyed the most about this game wasn’t just the fast-paced nature of the game, the fact that it resembled Mega Man so well, or the crazy fun powers you get, but rather the backstory you get to enjoy. Now I know from the look and feel of the game that the stories are more lighthearted and closer to the background, which is fine by me, but the moments where the game cuts back to the protagonist’s past were the best parts, as it not only gave me an idea as to who Spectre Knight really is, but even how the whole Enchantress’s Tower issue came to light. That, and the noble sacrifice SK makes in the end just makes the whole package that much sweeter. My only real eyeroll I got from the game was the underwhelming final boss.

Aesthetic-wise, everything is so good. Between the nostalgic 8-bit graphical style filled with vibrant colors, the strong and somewhat weighty sound effects, and Jake Kaufman’s musical score that is, erm, music to my ears, the visual and auditory work on this collection of games only adds to the enjoyment that this treasure trove provides.

I’ll make it simple: if you or anyone you know likes VIDEO GAMES, play this series of games. The only real negative trait they all share is that they’re all short games, but that only proves why it’s worth getting them all. These are games created by people who knew exactly how new games should be put together. Why more devs don’t give the “best parts of the past” method a try, I’ll never know. Thanks for reading!

98002990.review:
[b]Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove[/b] is a very interesting package. There’s a lot to talk about since there are, technically, 5 games in it. I will review each game separately, and then add my thoughts about the bundle itself.

[b]Shovel Knight: Shovel of Hope[/b] is the main game, the first one released, the one with more care put into, and the basis for all the other games, in a number of ways. As the screenshots suggest, the game is a homage to many NES games. If you like pixel art, and chiptunes, you’ll love the graphics and the music. The controls are also a throwback to these days, almost to a fault. Shovel Knight plays a lot like Link in Zelda 2, while being able to bounce off enemies after a “downstab”, almost like Scrooge McDuck’s pogo bounce in Duck Tales. 
There are also relics,  that work exactly like the NES Castlevania sub-weapons, with legally distinct axes and crosses, the same energy system (using potions instead of hearts to refill) and, by default, the same command to activate them (up + attack). You can (and should) change the commando to a single button, though, and you’ll need when/if you get the  dash. The sub-weapons are permanent, though, you’ll need to buy it from a shopper (strangely) hidden in a chest. If you miss him, you can find him at the town after the stage. Either way, you’ll have to buy from him, an even stranger decision.
This game uses a map to select its stages, similar to Super Mario Bros 3. There are the main stages, wandering enemies, bonus stages and secret stages. You can revisit stages, if you want to grind money for upgrades, or if you forgot a collectible. It is a bit of a short game, something that can be said about all games, but it’s fun nonetheless. 
The story is good too, a story of a grieving knight that gave up on adventuring, getting back to save the world from the Enchantress. There’s somber moments, humorous parts and a nice twist. It’s a pretty good game overall.

The second game is [b]Plague of Shadows[/b]. It’s the only game which you can’t buy separately. There is a reason for that. 
All games from this package heavily recycle assets from Shovel Knight: Shovel of Hope, be graphics, songs, bosses, you name it. But none other is more blatant than this game, since it uses a barely modified map. The secret parts of the game are different, but the main path, hell, even the map is the same.
That wouldn't be so bad if Plague Knight was such a terrible character to control. His jump is just terrible, with an abysmal height. He has a double jump, and a chargeable third jump. Sometimes you need these 3 jumps to get into places where Shovel Knight just needed one and a bouce. Worse yet, Plague is incapable of shooting his potions directly forward without a late game optional upgrade. In fact, I don’t think you can shoot forward on air at all, he will always shoot it diagonally down. There are a lot of customization for his potions and his charged jump, which counts as an attack, but they all feel off. You also have different sub-weapons, but they use a energy bar instead of a number system, and you need to find a relic AND the seller to actually have it. 
What makes it worse is, since PoS’s stages are mostly reused from Shovel Knight, none the stages aren’t built with Plague’s strange abilities in mind. 
The story is nice, though. It happens at the same time at Sword of Hope, and details Plague’s own agenda. Very straightforward, but cute. 
From what I’ve read, PoS wasn’t very well received at launch by its Kickstart backers, so the next expansion needed to be be very different.


[b]Specter of Torment[/b] is a different beast altogether. It’s a dark prequel to the Shovel of Hope story
SoT graphics are (usually) gloomier, the songs have been remixed, it actually feels like a different game. The story is significantly darker; it follows Specter Knight’s story to recruit 8 knights for the Enchantress and get his life back. The story takes a few turns, and it is very enjoyable, arguably better than Shovel of Hope’s story.
Specter’s playing style is interesting: while standing, he uses his scythe to attack. On air, he uses something called Dash Slash; enemies and obstacles will be market with a gash, and you dash directly into it, giving Specter a kind of a double jump. It’s a very interesting gameplay style, and the stages were remodeled to accommodate his moveset. He also has sub-weapons, which you "buy" with red skulls, hidden in all stages.
Even the stage selection is different: You don’t use a map at all, instead there’s a stage selection, almost like Mega Man. In fact, there are even events that happen after a few bosses are defeated, just like later Mega Man/X/Zero games.
I liked this one a lot, even more than Shovel of Hope.

The last main campaign of the package is [b]King of Cards[/b]. His gameplay style is very interesting: he uses a shoulder tackle, similar to Wario’s attack, but when it bumps into an enemy, breakable obstacles or most walls, King Knight rebounds into a spinning jump, that works similarly to Super Mario World’s spinning jump. The comparisons with the Mario 2D games don’t stop there, though: We’re back to a map similar to the Mario games, the stages are smaller but more numerous, not all stages finish with a boss battle. Actually, with most of bosses are roaming enemies. 
The platforming by itself is fun, but that’s not all that is to do in the game. There is a card game. Ther a few stages dedicated to the card game. Winning all matches is not necessary, but winning against every opponent gives you an excellent extra boss, so that’s nice, I guess.
The story is what killed it for me. It’s really bad, infuriating in some parts. It’s actually kinda reminiscent of [spoiler]Star Wars III: Revenge of the Sith[/spoiler], believe it or not. [spoiler]It’s about a petulant child who really believes he should have absolute power despite being immature and unprepared. That’s the entire joke of game, or at least a set up for a joke that never comes. Instead, the King Knight allies himself with the Enchantress, and betrays every single character he had met, including his mother, that pampered him throughout the campaign[/spoiler]. [spoiler]He even order the Enchantress’ minions to burn the cards, just make sure this story was as pointlessly mean spirited as possible.[/spoiler] I hated it, to the point where I felt I should stop playing the rest of the game altogether.

That being said, I played a bit of Shovel Knight Showdown. It’s a platform fighting game, but not a very good one. It reuses mechanics and assets from all Shove Knight games. I wish I could say more, but it didn’t grab me, specially after the King of Cards campaign.

And that’s Treasure Trove. All games have unlockables, like a sound test and a stupidly hard New Game+, plus small challenges. By themselves, the games are not that strong (specially King of Cards and Showdown), but as a bundle, it’s a strong recommendation.

97618499.review:
Good old school style action platformer. Plenty of content as it has 4 campaigns. Plague Knight and Specter Knight are mostly retreads with a different playstyle, story and some unique content in each. King Knight's campaign is very different and unique in its own way with both unique levels plus a card minigame you can play throughout it.

The biggest complaint I have about this is that it's mostly too easy in terms of real challenge. Deaths mostly come via insta-death in pits. Actual enemies and bosses will rarely ever kill you as not only is there an abundance of health everywhere, but you get items and powers that allow you to heal yourself instantly or let you make yourself temporarily invulnerable. King Knight's attacks randomly shoot hearts out of the enemies to heal yourself with. If you want a real challenge, you have to intentionally gimp yourself by not collecting health or using these items/powers.

97494235.review:
[b]Shovel Knight[/b] is probably overall the best retro throwback platformer on Steam. It's a very polished game, with lots of content, great pixel art and an amazing soundtrack. The controls are smooth, the balance is tight, and the game is a complete joy from start to finish. Just keep in mind that this is an actually challenging game with a level of difficulty similar to actual NES games from the 90's, don't expect a chill game to button mash through.

[b]Treasure Trove[/b] is a collection of all four Shovel Knight campaigns, each being roughly 10 hours long. All but [b]Plague of Shadows[/b] can also be [url=https://store.steampowered.com/search/?term=Shovel+Knight&developer=Yacht+Club+Games]bought separately[/url] as standalone games.

[h1]Shovel of Hope:[/h1]
This is the game that started it all. Think [url=store.steampowered.com/app/237630]DuckTales[/url] meets [url=store.steampowered.com/app/363440]Mega Man[/url]. Shovel Knight has a short range melee attack and when jumping he can point his shovel down allowing him to pogo off enemies or obstacles. During the course of the game he also acquires many relics which are essentially Mega Man style weapons. This is a level based platformer where you have to beat each level (and its boss) in one sitting. There are checkpoints used for respawning but the game only saves after beating a boss. Bosses are honestly not that difficult, especially if you spam items, but the platforming can be very challenging and demanding. Oftentimes you're required to execute a very precise sequence, e.g. pogo off these 3 enemies, then jump on that crumbling block, all the while dodging projectiles, over a pit of spikes. Most of the difficulty comes from the knockback mechanic (think Castlevania on the NES), and unlike the other playable characters Shovel Knight has no air recovery options, if you're hit mid-air you will plummet down and probably die instantly.

Honestly, Shovel is probably overall the weakest campaign in this package, it's a very solid platformer for sure but feels pretty basic compared to the expansions. Which is actually not a bad thing as it already was a pretty high bar.

[h1]Plague of Shadows:[/h1]
When you first start this campaign you might think that Plague Knight's moveset is bizarre and unwieldy and you'll die a few times in the very first level. But, after coming to grips with the controls and getting a few upgrades it actually becomes very, very fun. Plague Knight has an insane amount of mobility, he can launch himself in any direction in mid-air, quickly covering a lot of distance, he can triple jump and float, he can create up to 4 platforms in the air to help him zig-zag around pretty much any obstacle. And his massive arsenal of fully customizable bombs (you can change casing/powder/fuse etc at any time using a hotkey) allows him to easily shred through bosses.

But ultimately, this was the first expansion pack and it's definitely the most budget one. Plague largely reuses all the same levels and bosses as in Shovel, with only a small number of unique sections added here and there and a couple of new boss fights. It's essentially just a retread but with a higher skill ceiling. The story is lots of fun though, you play as a mad scientist with his own secret lair and minions, and then it turns into a very wholesome romance.

[h1]Specter of Torment:[/h1]
This is probably the smoothest game in this collection. Specter Knight has an amazing and easy to learn moveset, he can wall run/jump and dash attack (basically the same as Bash in [url=store.steampowered.com/app/387290]Ori[/url], but you can only do it in two diagonal directions). This works on enemies, projectiles and lamps, when you're below an object you dash through it upwards, and vice versa. Specter Knight also has a large arsenal of "curios", including an estus flask like healing item, various projectile attacks, and some more interesting abilities, e.g. creating a clone of himself, slowing down time or even dashing through walls to home onto an enemy. Specter's campaign features all new levels, which are better designed than the base Shovel campaign, both visuals and level design wise. The story is very interesting too, it's a prequel to Shovel, and explains how Specter came to be in service of the Enchantress, how he died and why is he a ghost now.

The only downside is, Specter is way too strong, and the estus mechanic makes him nigh impossible to kill, since simply hitting any enemy including a boss regenerates his "mana" allowing you to spam the estus almost indefinitely. You can face tank and first try every boss fight that doesn't have bottomless pits. And the first armor upgrade allows you to survive spikes and bottomless pits at the cost of some health and mana, further removing challenge.

[h1]King of Cards:[/h1]
This is the final and most lavish campaign, which is very fitting for the self-centered buffoon that is King Knight. This is the swan song of the series and the developers tried to put in as many bells and whistles as they could. There's a card game, Joustus, which is its own beast and while it can be ignored completely you might feel left out as the story revolves around it and winning matches is required for unlocking all upgrades. Personally, I didn't have too many problems with the card game, but it can be heavy on RNG, even if you know what you're doing.

As for the platforming gameplay, King Knight's moveset is small at first, he can dash horizontally and if he hits something (anything really, as long as it's not a cushioned wall), he will bounce back and do a ballerina spin which can be used to pogo on enemies and obstacles. This allows for some interesting and challenging platforming, which becomes even more fun as you unlock his other abilities. With some upgrades King can dash vertically as well, suspend himself in a bubble (allowing you to chain multiple dashes), or unleash a powerful combo with a fire sword easily decimating bosses.

The production values are much higher than the other campaigns, there are many completely new bosses and locations, and very little is recycled. This time around the game is split into 4 large worlds Super Mario World style, with many levels being optional or available only through secret exits. The story is once again a prequel where we take control of another villainous character, but unlike Plague and Specter there's no subversion here, King Knight is selfish and evil all the way through, which makes his interactions with other characters incredibly hilarious.

97349836.review:
Shovel Knight Treasure Trove has an absurd amount of content:

-4 full campaigns which on average take 8 hours each (Plague of Shadows has a bunch of rehashed content, but is still worth going through. Overall, the campaigns are pretty clearly King of Cards >> Shovel of Hope > Specter of Torment >>> Plague of Shadows in terms of quality. However you should play them all and in order)
-A challenge mode that will probably take you another 10+ hrs to clear if you're so inclined. Some of this is rehashed content made harder for a challenge but quite a bit of it is new screens of pure platforming
-New Game+, collectibles, "Feats" (in-game achievements), etc ... you can spend a lot of time here
-A Smash-like fighting game, with a full Story Mode, unlockables, the works. I didn't find this that interesting but hey it's cool that it's there. Impressive more than anything

Needless to say, Shovel Knight is ... an accomplishment. It took 7 years to make it all and it shows. But it's not just quantity over quality: the platforming is polished,  the mechanics are inventive, and the story and world is filled with charm. Some of it is a tad easy for my taste (especially the boss battles) but uh, the rest of the world seems to think this game is hard if anything, so most players will be adequately challenged.

Play it. It's good. Start digging!

97328764.review:
One of the few fountains of endless perfection that exists in this world. Where do I even start?

I guess with how it stands among the greatest Kickstarter success stories. It made and delivered on numerous, onerous promises it didn't have to. It released on multiple platforms, and it utilized each one's strengths in different ways: the Wii U gamepad can be used to switch items mid-game; the 3DS 3D effect is fully realized and improves the aesthetic in a subtle but meaningful way; and both platforms support Amiibo. None of what I've listed so far even matter in the grand scheme of things, but these bells and whistles are a microcosm of the attention to detail and genuine passion that went into all aspects of Shovel Knight.

Each of the three (free) DLCs is better than the previous, with the latter two constituting entirely distinct experiences from the base game. Each one was unabashed in its execution, ostensibly carefree about whether it eclipsed the base game — which they all do, in the best way possible. The movement mechanics are all fully conceived, the unlockable weapons are all new every time, and new, unique subsystems that pertain to the main characters in theme and personality are introduced with each DLC. The King of Cards DLC even has its own invented card game that was far from a distraction from the main platforming; I thoroughly enjoyed and looked forward to each match in the card game, as it was well designed and fun.

The music, written by Jake Kaufman, is something I can't describe without resorting to banal verbiage such as "genius," "masterpiece," or "perfect." The all-chiptune composition makes use of the same waveforms as the Famicom's VRC6 sound chip, famously included in Akumajou Densetsu/Castlevania III. This chip represents the full realization of the NES/Famicom's musical aesthetic, in a "this is how it felt when we were kids playing it" sort of way. The numerous channels gave Kaufman the flexibility to write some incredible counterpoint and texture into the tracks. Above all, they sound great, they're highly memorable, and they're thematically appropriate for each setting. Think "Mozart" levels of "wow, every single track is excellent and makes it seem like he doesn't even have to try."

The sprite artwork is similarly the full realization of the NES/Famicom's visual style. It almost certainly uses more colors and sprites per scan line (but who's counting?), the aspect is different, and the vertical resolution may be slightly different, but the sizing and relative scale of everything is convincingly Famicom. It has parallax, which very few NES games did, but Shovel Knight sells it. I'd imagine it technically matches the capabilities of the SNES/Super Famicom, but, through and through, the Famicom is the scripture this game drew from. I understand that grand claims over the music may be contentious, but I can't imagine a single other game that nails 4th-gen graphics in the same way Shovel Knight does.

As for the gameplay... just play the game. If you're reading this, you already played it, or you're going to anyway. Buy the game, download the game, install the game, and then play the game. I know you're not going to regret it, you know you're not going to regret it, so just save us all some time and play the game. It's the second coming of Jesus, it'll do your taxes, and you're going to play it. You're going to love it, and you're going to wish you didn't waste your time reading this when you could have been playing it. Perfect game, perfect music, perfect art, and, may God have mercy on us all, this game is worth an organ donation or two.

96822956.review:
Una obra maestra de los juegos de plataformas, no verás muchos juegos con un nivel de detalle y esfuerzo tan grande como lo han puesto los desarrolladores de este juego. Esta versión, incluye todas las campañas de Shovel Knight que se han lanzado desde su lanzamiento y cada una es distinta de las demás en cuanto gameplay e historia se refiere.

Shovel of Hope (8/10)
La aventura original de Shovel Knight recoge elementos característicos de los mejores juegos de la NES como el moveset de Ducktales, el mapa de Super Mario Bros 3, el diseño de niveles, de personajes y de música de los Mega Man, las paredes ocultas y el sistema de salud de los Castlevania y un largo etc y los junta todos para crear un juegazo. Mi unica queja del juego es que la historia es bastante meh y que los objetos están desbalanceados.

Plague of Shadows (7/10)
Esta fue la primera campaña extra creada para el juego y se nota, Plague Knight tiene un moveset bastante variado ya que es posible customizarlo a tu gusto pero hay un problema con esto, los niveles son exactamente los mismos que los de Shovel of Hope y al estar diseñados para Shovel Knight en mente no tienen en cuenta la gran movilidad que tiene Plague Knight en comparación y con determinadas builds puedes pasarte un nivel entero casi volando y se pierde toda dificultad, aún así, no deja de ser divertido ya que hay más coleccionables que buscar por los niveles, hay muy poca música nueva pero esa poca es bastante buena y la historia y personajes son superiores a Shovel of Hope, haciendo incluso que Plague Knight tenga más personalidad que Shovel Knight. 

Specter of Torment (9/10)
Aquí fue donde los creadores se la sacaron muy fuertemente. La movilidad de esta campaña es la hostia y la mejor de todas, la historia es bastante chula y mejor que las anteriores, la banda sonora original si bien rehúsa alguna que otra música de Shovel of Hope, en su mayoría es bastante buena y la originalidad de los niveles y mecánicas es bastante creativa, no hay otro juego en el que puedas hacer skate sobre raíles con una guadaña. 
Mi única queja es que es más corta que las otras campañas.

King of Cards (10/10)
Para mi, esta es la mejor campaña de las 4. El gameplay inspirado en los Wario Land es muy bueno, la historia es normalita pero esta bien, se sustituye el patron de niveles que ha habido en las otras campañas de nivel muy largo con muchas mecánicas con un jefe al final inspirado en los Mega Man por   niveles cortos que giran en torno de una sola mecánica y la expanden todo lo que pueden y que además tienen salidas secretas el cual está insipirado en Super Mario Bros 3 y creo que es mucho mejor así ya que incita mucho más a la exploración de los niveles y es menos tedioso pasar niveles cortos. Pero lo mejor de todo de King of Cards es el nuevo añadido que es un juego de cartas llamado Justus, es tan bueno, que a mi que no me gustan los juegos de cartas, me ha viciado bastante. Espero que los desarrolladores hagan algún spin-off centrado solo en el Justus porque es un vicio total.



Esta versión incluye un juego de lucha llamado Showdown pero lo he estado jugando y no me ha llamado la atención. En general, el juego merece muchísimo la pena y espero con ansias el próximo juego de Yacht Club Games.

PD: Mona besto waifu

96717272.review:
I want to start by saying this is *exclusively a review for shovel of hope*. I have played very little of specter of torment and none of the other 2 campaigns. And specter of torment actually fixes my main issue. 

For the most part, Shovel Knight is a great game. It does almost everything right. Unfortunately, I found it extremely frustrating and not very fun due to one simple issue. The controls are just too slow. First of all, I have an extremely high threshold for responsiveness and speed in games. Anything short of Celeste can be frustrating to me. In reality, Shovel of Hope is pretty responsive. But it still often feels like an input can just be too slow. 

A lot of the time, the game just throws things at you without them being visible until they've already almost hit you. This, in and of itself, is not a problem, but the shovel is fairly slow, meaning that it's often impossible to react to things. I personally hate being out of control in this way. 

A related, though slightly different issue comes down to how many blind spots you have. There is no way to swing up, which means that often flying enemies placed near platforms just straight up cannot be attacked. On flat ground, you could just walk to the side, but on platforms you can't do this often, which can lead to unfair gameplay. 

These issues are ones that will not ruin the experience for most people, but they did for me. Specter of Torment fixes the unresponsive controls issue, so I kind of wish I owned Shovel of Hope on its own to place this review exclusively there. Even with this issue, I still played through almost the entire campaign. This review is negative because I didn't enjoy the one campaign that I nearly finished.

96239405.review:
[h1]A well-polished gem in the retro trove[/h1]

Shovel Knight pays a passionate tribute to the 8-bit era games that we older generation players grew up with and embraced. As the titular hero, you set out across the kingdom to find treasures, overcome obstacles and fight the knights of the Order of No Quarter. The gameplay is quite fine-tuned to suit players overall and has attained a fine difficulty balance.

Treasure Trove also includes other titles that focus on a few other knights, which I played in the story's chronological order. Each of their story modes presents unique features and movesets that act like its own game while sharing the memorable cast and same levels, albeit re-implemented to suit each playable character. King of Cards is quite vast with an optional card game that expands the content while Plague of Shadows features a system that allows you to customize your moves, which took me a while to figure out at first but was well worth overall (with a charming love story to boot). The only pack that didn't stick with me long was Showdown, which is rather arena-based and confined within its own fighting core with nary any story to boot.

The soundtrack is faithfully chiptune-based, even designed on actual hardware used for 8-bit consoles. The composer manages to make each soundtrack memorable that suits the mood and environment of each level or event; my favorite would be the melancholic and dreamy (duh) tune "Requiem".

Shovel Knight is a game that is rich with contents and ticks all the boxes required to make an addictive, fun and satisfying game. For that, Treasure Trove justifies its retail value more than set. A must-have for fans of action-platformers and 8-bit classics.

95351819.review:
So far I've beaten shovel of hope and plague of shadows, and im working on specter of torment.

Shovel of Hope is amazing -- the platforming is certainly punishing but when it comes to platformers difficult generally means more fun. Centering the game around money makes for a good incentive to actually fight the enemies rather than skip past them, but the death mechanic can really screw you over if you end up dying in an awkward spot. This also means you have to keep spending money to avoid that money getting lost -- a penny saved is a penny stuck in a money bag tucked under a platform with no way for you to reach it. The bosses are a ton of fun. I dont really tend to follow stories often in games but the characters seem fun in their own ways and the connection between shovel knight and shield knight is very cute.

Plague of Shadows did not click with me at first -- the weapon is so awkward because the angle you throw it at can never hit any enemies. That was until I learned I was playing the game wrong the entire time. The true way to experience plague of shadows is to craft the most crazy and unique combinations of casings, powder, and fusings. For example, at first I thought the lob casing, cascade powder, and remote fuse were all useless. The lob casing has a terrible angle that couldn't hit an enemy right in front of you, the cascade powder limits you to one bomb and needs to cover distance and is hard to control. The remote fuse also essentially limits you to one bomb. But combine all three of those together ? you get one of the coolest weapons ive ever seen in a game. The lob casing gives the cascade powder the necessary distance and the cascade powder allows the lob casing to hit grounded enemies in front of you. The remote fuse gives the cascade powder the control it needs and it doesnt matter that the remote fuse limits you to one bomb because the cascade powder does that anyways. This all results in a remote death bomb that drops down on enemies at your command. This cool combination isn't going to work for every enemy or boss though, but that only means you get to come up with more clever combinations. Coming up with a new combination of casing powder and fuse for different areas and bosses is so cool and what makes the game fun. Also the characters in this game are so so so so cute.

I haven't gotten too far into specter of torment but it seems pretty fun. Again I'm not very much of a story person but the story does seem to be shaping up to be pretty good. Character controls fun.

Have not started King of Cards but I look forward to it.

Overall, Treasure Trove is a super awesome experience but to be entirely honest I don't think it's worth the 40 dollars. You aren't really paying for 4 games in my opinion you're paying for 4 different versions of the same game. The reimagines are super clever and there are certainly different gameplay elements but I wouldn't recommend spending 40 dollars on one platformer with 4 different characters. But if you catch it on sale for a decent price or money isn't really an issue for you, I would definitely go ahead and buy it. I think every fan of the platforming genre at some point in their life has to play Shovel of Hope though.

And yes, the soundtrack is amazing.

93561742.review:
DIFFICULT, yet rewarding. An exceptional platformer. Scratch that - four exceptional platformers. You get four games in one with the Treasure Trove, and each plays very differently.

Shovel of Hope is platforming on the bleeding edge, just you, your found power ups, and your shovel against the world. No frills to the gameplay with a beautiful execution, excellent and memorable level design, a fantastic soundtrack, and a serviceable and occasionally endearing story. 

Plague of Shadows is a Bomberman variant that takes you through remixed versions of SoH's levels. I found this gameplay to be the least entertaining, but the story is by far and away the best one. Plague Knight is so incredibly cute and his quest is interesting and unexpected, with the perfect amount of cheese.

Specter of Torment is a hack-and-slash platformer variant that I adored - it takes the cake for gameplay in my opinion. It introduced a non-linear mission set up and some additional 'dream' levels, along with an entirely reworked hero. 

King of Cards is a platformer with a card playing mini-game attached. This...was a little odd, though it does help to make this installment stand out as a unique game itself. Featuring a 'choose-your-path' adventure map, shorter and more abundant levels, and the aforementioned card game is fairly entertaining. Probably the weakest in the series, but still a very good platformer.

These games are very hard, but the developers keep close relations with the speedrunning community, so if you enjoy the rush of blitzing a platformer level that you've done a hundred times before like it's the old Nintendo days, you'll find that rush here. Me, I'll just be happy to beat them all. Like I said at the very beginning, they're HARD. Still recommended.

92558809.review:
What a fantastic collection! I've just played it (the whole collection) on the Wii U, that's why my timer shows only 94 minutes as my total play time. I'm basically overdosing in Shovel Knight, so I won't play it for now. But here's what I think of the whole package:

1. Shovel of Hope
It's a fantastic game. Certainly could be better, but it's a stellar first entry for the studio. The art is beautiful, the music is great, the atmosphere is also very good. Not much to complain here. The game is fair, a little bit tough to master and overall a great experience.
Score: 8.5/10

2. Plague of Shadows
The first sequel (I don't consider them expansions, extensions or DLC. To me they're sequels) is a little shy design-wise in that many levels are taken straight from the first game, except for an extra little section in each of them. Still, Plague Knight is a chaotic fun mess to control, which gives the game an extra challenge (it takes a bit to get used to, but once you start getting the hang of it, the game flows nicely). Her character development is also much better than Shovel Knight's very basic story. The world they built for Plague Knight within the first game's world is very well made. I recommend this one ONLY if you've played Shovel of Hope.
Score: 9/10

3. Specter of Torment
Masterpiece. Their greatest achievement. If they ended the series here I'd totally forgive them. There's absolutely nothing to be critical of here: the level design is their best yet. The revamped levels feel tailor-made to Specter Knight. The music is SO TASTY, the baroque style complements the character so much! Not to mention that many pieces were rearranged to fit Specter Knight better. The story is the deepest out of the whole series (which shouldn't say much, but I consider this to be the one Shovel Knight game with a proper story). The art is gorgeous, their best work out of the first three games. Finally, the whole atmosphere is perfectly built. It's a pity this is the shortest of the campaigns, but WOW did they deliver an excellent game. This is a must play. Get it for full price, on sale, as part of the whole package, as a standalone title, I don't care, just do yourself a favor and play this one!
Score: 10/10

4. King of Cards
The longest game in the package... I almost abandoned the game in the beginning, but I'm so glad I decided to stay! While most of this game feels like a step back from the previous title, they still managed to improve in some areas. Levels are now shorter, but there are also more of them. The overworld is a bit less linear than that of the first two games. Monarch/King Knight isn't half as fun to control as the other characters, in my opinion, but they're still very good. The Joustus game that is the premise of the whole main game is a bit confusing at first, but there is something addicting in its formula. I did end up being Queen of Cards, but it was a bit of a rough road to get there, especially without cheat cards (which are an option - the whole Joustus game is optional). Back to the main game, the absolutely best thing it brings to the table, alongside its sense of humor and world-building, are the graphics. The whole game looks gorgeous, but there is a secret boss battle that looks fantastic. The final boss and the levels leading up to it are also great. But there is a secret area accessed via the third world that is quite possibly the most beautiful art that could be built with the tools they've made this game. I was in awe. It's a truly breathtaking and jaw-dropping little secret. These are the main reasons I loved exploring all of this game's nooks and crannies. It is a rougher ride if you're coming straight from the other three games, especially coming from Specter of Torment, but it's also a worthwhile ride if you decide to stick with it to the end.
Score: 9/10

5. Shovel Knight Showdown
This is the only game in the package that didn't really make me fall in love with it. Part of the reason is that I can only play single-player during the pandemic. But even the single-player story mode didn't feel very good. I ended up not playing through it all, but I'm sure many people would enjoy it greatly.
Score: 6.5/10

In the end I only have a minor complaint about the whole package: the Brazilian Portuguese translation felt rushed. I don't know if this is Yacht Club's, the translator's, or everyone's fault, but it surely took away some of the game's charm. Translation isn't an easy feat, and there ARE good solutions, but there are many more bad ones that hurt the final experience. Not to mention that body swap doesn't seem to work in Portuguese (and also not to mention the complete lack of gender neutral options in Portuguese). Still the games are fantastic in English.
Collective Score (NOT the average of the other scores): 8.7/10

Shovel Knight is (in my honest opinion) one of the best 2D side-scrolling games in existence. The controls feel better and more responsive than just about any of the other competition. Also, the fact that you get 4.5 games (the .5 being Showdown) is a great deal with each campaign taking about 5-8 hours on your first play-through depending on skill level and level of completion.
This is one of those games that encourages multiple playthroughs and the achievements add a decent challenge. One of the tougher achievements that was fun to get is Checkpointless which requires you to destroy the checkpoints in every level you play, forcing you to start over at the beginning of the (Pretty long) level. However, as challenging as some of those achievements can be, the game never feels unfair or cheap (mostly owing to the aforementioned amazing controls). If you keep at it, you'll get better and eventually succeed.

91687166.review:
At its best, this is a collection of four decent length retro platformers. There's mild RPG elements, alright writing, and an emphasis on finding secrets and then using them to customize your play style.

Each game is *mostly* composed of the same array of levels, but the formula shifts as you play on, and everything feels relatively fresh throughout.

The place where Shovel Knight makes or breaks itself is in the movement tech, and for me it was pretty inconsistent. Sometimes it felt great and I could flow-state through levels, sometimes hitboxes were inscrutable.

A lot of the game's secrets revolve around smashing open walls, and the game becomes considerably easier the more secrets you unlock, so be prepared to get frustrated if you rush.

If you're very good at platforming, I suspect speedrunning is pretty fun for each of these games, and if you're more into storytelling than action gameplay, the writing here really isn't that bad. 

Overall, I think this is a really safe purchase if you like platformers, but could be super frustrating if you have a negative reaction to instadeath pits, spikes, and precision pogos.

91083800.review:
I'd recommend this when it's on sale. 
Overall, there's a good gameplay loop between the different knights, each is fun and interesting in their own way. Plague Knight is pretty repetitive, gameplay-wise, but the research and upgrade mechanics offset it. 
My only real complaint is that the level design can be frustratingly bad. Some will brush it off as "the game's just hard, git gud" but this isn't a complaint about difficulty. A difficult level has segments that compliment the abilities of the character but still require a significant amount of skill to overcome. A badly designed level will outright sabotage/work against the mechanics that have been put in place, just to artificially boost difficulty. Unfortunately, the level design can lean a bit further towards the latter. Thankfully, this isn't always the case.
Overall, I enjoy the game. The level design can be frustrating, as said before, but it's not really enough to write the game off completely. It's a perfectly serviceable game that I come back to, every once in a while, just for a fun way to kill time.

Well the game is a good homenage and offers 5 well crafted and good games; wich ill explain:

1-Shovel of hope: Your tipical megaman plataformer, full of surprises, adventures, and charming characters. One minor complaint is that there are things for ceartian vearsions wich made me piss off when i first knew about it. But still its good and defnently the first one to play. (9.5/10) 
TIP: None

2-Plauge of shadows: Well.... from what i heard of this DLC, it was sort of the bad one of all the DLC. But hey, dont let the fans tell you what to do; after beating this DLC i managed to master the ''ways of the plauge'' hee hee... Well, complaints for this DLC are none; its just that it gets some getting used to. (8/10) 
TIP: Look for all the chipter coins on the last stages, since the main stages are more fun to re-play.

3-Specter of torment: This DLC is kinda Shovel of hope remixed and re-imaginated. It features good mechanics and a good basic moveset. I think that most people should apreciate the story as well, i mean, the story was good, but not like shovel of hope. It would be nice if some people just would apreciate the story more. (10/10) 
TIP: Most of the red skulls are out of sight, requiering some later items to access, one boss order suggestion would be to have the hover plume before mole knight is done.

4-King of cards: This DLC is kinda one of the best standing between shovel of hope and specter of torment. I get it that the levels are more shorter, but there are soooo much twists and turns thats it kinda makes the game more fun. This is kinda the best last DLC that everyone wanted. And the story is kinda funny and child-ish but thats expected from a teen (or kid idk his age) that just wants to be good at a card game and becomes a usurper at the end. (shut up comment section, everyone knows that he becomes a king at the end). (8.5/10)
TIP: If you think that youll get someting for exchange out of all the merit medals sorry to tell you this but its just for 100% clompetition stats and nothing else. 
-JOUSTUS: Look.... i get it that most people arent good at card games but give joustus a try, its good and test your abilities to solve problems outside of the main game. Joustus may sound like a way to make a playthough longer, but its acctually a nice change of pace. (69/10)
TIP: Getting the house champ achivement might help you 100% your joustus library. And for the Hey thats mine achivement, you just need LUCK; you heard me right: YOU HAVE TO BE LUCKY TO GET THIS ACHIEVEMENT.

5-SHOWDOWN: So Yatch club games once sat and thouth: ''HEY! HOW BOUT WE DO A COPY OF SMASH BROTHERS BUT WITH OUR CHARACTERS?'' And thus this DLC is born. Its kinda like smash brothers, but you unlock things as you spend more time battleling your friends or a CPU. Its a nice change of pace from what we know. Some extra characters are in there, with their own movesets. (10/10)
TIP:

CONCLUSION: Shovel knight treasure trove, is the BEST indie game collection of Yatch club games. Its well made, stands out for tons of people and hey, its worth the investment. Youll surely have a blast with the game. Now we wait till Yatch club is done with DIG, Pocket dungeon Or maybe something entirely new. Whatever the case, I am glad to have this indie GEM as one of my steam games.

P.S: Sorry if my english typing is bad, its my second language.
EXTRA: How about we make Joustus a REAL card game?

90338294.review:
Game: Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove
Rating: 10/10
TL:DR: Most underrated addictive game.
Review: Shovel Knight Treasure Trove is a platformer/combat game, It's a pretty good game with interesting 8bit graphics to make you feel the old times of megaman and such as its inspired by megaman.
The soundtrack is well done, you can listen to most of it to vibe, Doing homework, Studying, Takin a break etc.
The game has 4 campaigns to play from, starting with:
SHOVEL OF HOPE
The story is also well written, Its about shovel knight and shield knight, As one day shield knight had been gone missing after their adventure to the Tower of Fate, Which lead shovel knight to stop adventuring only to continue again later after a long period due to threat of the Order of the No Quarter, A group made by the enchantress with 8 strong knights that plan to take over everything!
First off, The mechanics and checkpoint systems are pretty good, Its not complicated and pretty simple although it does require a bit of skill and focusing  instead of playing freely.
The boss fights are also pretty good, you can beat the campaign in a good 8 hour sitting of fun! If you plan on getting all upgrades/relics/armors It could take a few more hours, But it is fun!
After you beat the game, You get to play New game + which is restarting the campaign but with all your upgrades except that its even harder, Less checkpoints, More damage from enemies, Meals are replaced with bombs!
If i were to give a rating to this campaign it would be 8.5/10 because it may not be best due to some reasons. But its great for a first campaign
PLAGUE OF SHADOWS
In this campaign, You play as plague knight, The story is sided with Shovel of Hope's story (same time) and it revolves on plague knight's quest to crafting the ultimate potion
The Soundtrack in this campaign is pretty okay, would pick shovel of hope's than this one.
The mechanics and upgrade system is pretty good and thought of well! You get to make your own interesting bomb combinations and mixes through upgrades and such.
I mean what is more interesting than bomb jumping into the air?
The story is also pretty well written and funny sometimes which really fits Plague knight's character!
The downside of this campaign is its levels are pretty similar to Shovel of Hope's which makes it a lil boring/uninteresting.
If i were to give a rating to this campaign it would be 8/10
SPECTER OF TORMENT
Play in this campaign as Specter knight in this awesome prequel to Shovel of Hope, With your quest to hire knights for the Order of the No quarter for the enchantress!
The story is probably the best out of the 4 campaigns, Saying so would spoil alot of it, But its pretty perfect. Even has alot of tragedy in it and is unexpected!
The mechanics and Upgrade systems are pretty great too, The attack system is good, You get to wall climb etc.
Level design is different too, It has all kinds of interesting things
The soundtrack is the best out of the 4 here as its basically every Shovel of Hope track but remixed!
Downside here is probably the content since its the shortest campaign which is pretty sad in my opinion, But i think its enough for its story.
The New game + in this one is more challenging too, Your mana and health get fused into one bar aka if you use a spell/curio your health gets reduced too. There is even like a timer, Every second a part of your health/mana bar is reduced which makes it even harder and more challenging to finish the level as quick as you can
If i were to give a rating to this campaign it would be 9.9/10
KING OF CARDS
Play in another awesome prequel as King knight on his main journey to become the king of Joustus!
The map and content in this campaign is around triple the content in any campaign, There is also a new thing to play called Joustus, which is like its own side story which is basically a cards style game, Its creative too! It has things like King Knights' personality like cheating, stealing cards.. etc.
The mechanics are great too! You get to shoulder bash enemies, Spin, Roll
Upgrades are wide in variety but a bit harder to get this time probably due to levels not paying much money because levels are shorter now.
The story is good, But not the best, Its a bit comedic sometimes as there are even new characters like King Knight's Mom and at the same time the story may feel silly/docuhebagy due to King knight's personality (he's an asshole)
The New game + for this campaign is actually hard, To use relics you need to pay money, You have less health etc.
If i were to rate this campaign i would give it 9/10


Meanwhile though since i talked about the 4 campaigns i want to talk about Showdown, a small gamemode thing outside the campaigns, Its a super smash bros like game where you get to play as 16 different characters from Shovel knight and Shield knight to Goldarmors (a basic enemy) Its very fun, Creative, One of the best things in shovel knight treasure trove.
Its extremely fun i dont even know how to express it!
Final things to talk about are the achievements for this game
They are sometimes fun, Sometimes tedious, Generally they are fun and feel satisfying but each campaign has painful achievements like speedrunning or checkpointless, If you are picking this game as a completionist, You will have pain. Trust me.
Its probably just time consuming and skill at the end though


I think Shovel knight treasure trove is a pretty worth game for 40$ You have 4 standalone games and a super smash bros like game so, 5 games for 40$ is generous
To probably excite you more, There are two spinoffs in the making:
Shovel knight Dig
Shovel knight: Pocket Dungeon
I hope you liked my review anyways, Dont forget to pick the game up :)

90042933.review:
To summarize, if you haven't played a shovel knight game, do it. They are fantastic platformers, and the perfect modern NES style game. There is a lot of this game though, so there's a lot to say regardless.
So I'm gonna rate my favorites from worst to best. But to be clear, none of these games are bad.

4: King Of Cards
Even though it introduces a lot, King of cards is definitely my least favorite. I'm not a card game guy. and I cannot fathom how annoying joust can be. But at least it's skippable. The levels are shorter, except there's more of them, and there are some cool and creative ideas in this one. But not the best. But you might like it! Good chance of it.

3: Shovel Of Hope (Shovel Knight)
An incredibly solid campaign. A pure adventure that will always be a blast to play. It's challenging, it's a jam. There is nothing wrong with this one

2: Specter Of Torment
Not only is this one incredibly pretty with visuals, AND extremely inventive with it's gameplay, the story is flawless. You go back and forth between the past and the present, learning about the characters, and why you are where you are. This one is a very impressive game. And not too long. You'll beat this one quick, but It'll be worth it.

1: Plague Of Shadows
I may be alone on this one, But I think plague of shadows is the best. The story is absolutely adorable, the levels are cool, and you can pull off some CRAZY stuff with the power-ups. I found myself experimenting a bunch with what I could do, which made for even more exciting gameplay. And you can dance. This one alone is a 10/10.

Anyway what are you doing. This is literally 4 games (Plus Showdown) for the price of one. Just get it

89858302.review:
This is definitely one of the best "retro" games you could ever purchase. The core game is already great on it's own, with its challenging levels, fun and creative level design, items and bosses, and even a big potential for speedruning, accompanied of wonderful chiptunes... and then there's the extra content.

Plague of Shadows... is OK. I like Plague Knight and I had fun playing through the campaign, but some elements like the bomb customization don't feel very useful at all, as you'll mostly end up sticking with one combination that you like. Even if it is still good, it's the only one that actually feels like DLC.

Specter of Torment is incredible and easily my favorite game of them all. The overhaul the game receives is spectacular and Specter Knight himself controls perfectly, plus the idea of having a "home" to return to after stages was genius. Hell, I even got invested in the story. Splendid.

Finally, after a bit of delay, we got King of Cards, and as usual, it was a blast to play through. Even though I personally wasn't a fan of the more bite-sized stages, it was more than made up with the fantastic new locations, and of course, the always on point gameplay. Plus, Joustus is simply a delight to play and waste hours on, trying to complete your collection.

Yacht Games put all their love and care into this project, and they went out of their way to deliver on everything they promised back when they started their Kickstarter, I admire their dedication to this project and I'm grateful for getting to play it, as I had a big smile on my face during the whole time I was playing this. Its only downside is that Plague of Shadows is a slightly sore thumb in the catalogue, but even then that's only due to how amazing the other games are. This is absolutely worth every one of your pennies, you need to play this.

87693794.review:
If you want to know why Shovel Knight has appeared as a cameo in basically every indie game ever made, well it's about time you see why. As a 2D platformer, the base game of Shovel Knight is still as amazing as it was when I first played it. Every pixel on the screen exists on screen for a reason - leading to densely designed levels that are constantly testing you and ramping up the challenge in a beautifully gradual way. There's tonnes of secrets to find if you know how to use the enemies to your advantage, one of the best soundtracks in any video game ever, and some very sweet dialogue to pep you up throughout your epic digging journey. I honestly really don't think the 'treasure trove' pack here is quite worth the high asking price considering I don't think the DLC is that great (unless you like replaying the exact same lengthy game over and over again with slightly different controls), but the base game is still as special as it ever was.

★★★★★★★★★☆

87496995.review:
The highest praise I can give this game is in my difficulty to find anything else to play that is remotely close to its amount of content  and level of polish. 
The love put into this experience bleeds out of every  crack; the sheer creativity never seems to run out. The soundtrack is so good that it justifies the individual tracks' inclusion as in-game collectables. To save anyone the time, that one song that you hope plays in every level you're about to start is called 'Strike the Earth'.

For the price of $45 Canadian, you get:
 - Four 8-15 hour-long campaigns, each with radically different move sets and mechanics.
 - A fully featured, highly addictive card game, complete with rares to collect.
 - A PvP/PvE mode with unlockable stages, character skins, and a fully-featured randomised 
    campaign/tournament mode.
 - The soundtracks of all four campaigns and an integrated music player.
 - 120 purpose-built challenge stages, 30 for each character move set.
 - New-Game-Plus for all campaigns that introduce gameplay mechanics different from the 
    first playthrough.
 - All non-challenge levels playable in local co-op
 - 100% compatible RGB keyboard support, with colour effects that change depending on 
    stage, completion, and sometimes syncs up directly with the in-game soundtrack
 
And all of it, by God, is without equal. Yacht Club Games has polished Shovel Knight to a mirror finish. If you have any interest in sidescrollers, even a passing one, then Shovel Knight will not only engage you, but will make the genre as a whole something you seek out more of.

86020831.review:
The original Shovel Knight game is a pretty good retro platformer, complete with pixelated graphics and annoying bottomless pits. I am playing the successive campaigns in order, and updating this review as I go. Overall, the Treasure Trove package isn't the cheapest and I wasn't as impressed by the first game as others. That said, there is sufficient quality - and in later campaigns, innovation! - that Shovel Knight definitely deserves a thumbs up.

SHOVEL OF HOPE:
It seems to me that the majority of people who were blown away by this game in 2014 (or 2021) simply lacked a "classical gaming education" with NES/SNES Mario, Megaman, the original Castlevanias, etc. What's here is all designed competently enough, but it's also all a little derivative of these earlier platformers - and, in my opinion, doesn't match the original experiences. Castlevania's music and whip are still more iconic, Mario's light vibe and less punishing level design are still more approachable, and Megaman's boss order still offers more freedom to the player. SoH is kind of a pastiche of all of these games' ideas (plus Link's downward thrust from Zelda II), and the few modern tweaks (like Dark Souls-esque gold drop at place of death) are imo just grating distractions from the core concept. Re the difficulty: Shovel Knight is neither easy enough to be a fun, relaxing romp (losing gold just absolutely sucks...), nor challenging enough to focus entirely on this aspect (unlike Super Meat Boy and Cuphead, which both do away with distractions and allow quicker replays of difficult platforming and ingenious bosses, respectively). SoH being up for GOTY I find especially confusing, when put up against much more innovative games from 2014 like Alien: Isolation, Divinity Original Sin, Valiant Hearts: The Great War, Child of Light, Hearthstone, Titanfall, Transistor; heck, even Shadow of Mordor and Far Cry 4. Guacamelee came out in 2013, and even that game brought more to the table with a brawler / platformer hybrid approach and unique Luchador theme that I hadn't seen before. Oh well, SoH is still a solid platformer and does provide 6ish hours of fun; so although it is not a masterpiece I can recommend it. 

PLAGUE OF SHADOWS:
Alright, now I'm starting to get the appeal of these games... Plague Knight has one of the coolest character designs out of the Knights, and perhaps with more exposure I am starting to appreciate the graphics in these games more. Scenes like Shovel Knight entering the village in the background while you sneak in via a secret tunnel are a great bit of "evil" fun, and there are many such nods to the original game throughout  (trading Chester "useless" artifacts from the first game that he will then sell to Shovel Knight also tickles me). Gameplay-wise, I have to admit that Plague of Shadows is a really well-done mixup of the original's concepts: Plague Knight controls in a very innovative way, more floaty but dissimilar to other platformers and much harder to master. Consequently, platforming difficulty is increased but bosses are actually a bit easier this time around, which imo fits into the evil power fantasy. My favorite addition is the ability to customize your bombs and moveset - imo, this adds real depth to the platforming and combat and is a great expansion of the first game. Mixing bomb fuses, casings, and powders also recalls the underappreciated bomb system from Assassin's Creed Revelations, except it is even more impactful in a tight platformer like this. Overall, experiencing Plague Knight has really shifted my opinion of the game - well done.

SPECTER OF TORMENT:
A little bit shorter and more streamlined than the previous two campaigns, but this one is just a more condensed kind of quality, with less annoyance and breaks in the enjoyment. The way Specter Knight controls, especially with the very fun Rail Mail, is a huge departure from Shovel Knight and Plague Knight. The wall-climbing is classic Ninja Gaiden added to the Shovel Knight pastiche, but the way Specter combines this with the diverse Curios and other abilities feels somehow fresh regardless - much more so than the original Shove Knight campaign. It's worth noting that compared to PoS, SoT is even more of a power trip: I absolutely crushed every boss, and even the platforming was simpler this time. But for this prequel story, with this character, it works for me! Spectre of Torment was the only campaign I thought ended too soon, and had enough depth to its mechanics to warrant many more hours of platforming: this is both a positive and a negative, but with the possibility of New Game+ and challenge runs like beating the game without Curios, I'll lean on the former.

KING OF CARDS:
In my opinion, the very best campaign of the lot, and a testament to the progress this team have made as developers since 2014's original Shovel Knight. By this point, the Treasure Trove package had already fully grown on me, and KoC *still* blew me away! Graphics, music, and story are as charming as ever (imo, the peak of the series), but where this campaign truly outshines its predecessors is in the quality and quantity of its gameplay. Firstly, the amount of variety that was squeezed out of a simple shoulder bash move is crazy, and most importantly finally feels like a totally new and unique platforming concept. Breaking up the levels into shorter, digestible sequences with a larger world map was also inspired, and the power creep in Plague of Shadows and Spectre of Torment was finally toned down: King Knight is strong, but challenge is present throughout the game this time like in the original Shovel Knight. Finally, Joustus! This card game not only provides an interesting protagonist motivation in the narrative, but is a very fun, fleshed-out puzzle game in its own right! I liked everything about it: its surprisingly deep tactics, strategic deck-building, and refreshing breaks from platforming were all amazing. King of Cards is Shovel Knight at its most realized version, and feels like the team applying everything they've learned so far to make a truly great game. 

CONCLUSION:
Simply put, the variety of campaigns and gameplay styles on offer here is fantastic. PoS, SoT, and KoC all make innovative and fun tweaks to the original Shovel Knight's platforming, and the final campaign especially is a top-notch champion in the genre. It's pretty incredible that all of this content plus Joustus (plus Showdown!) were free for the original backers. Now that's value, and respect for kickstarters! So despite finding the original 2014 Shovel Knight merely "good", I give the full Treasure Trove package a big thumbs up!

85554846.review:
In my opinion, this is a platformer masterpiece. As you've no doubt seen and heard, Shovel Knight is heavily inspired by the 8-bit platformers of the NES/SNES era and puts its own twist on things, such as light RPG elements involving upgrading your health, changing up your armor for different gameplay effects, and items that you can use for various purposes from a flame wand to an invincibility locket.

Some quality-of-life things are in this package, though. For one thing, each level has a certain number of checkpoints, and a dark souls-esque system exists where instead of losing a life upon death, all of your gold is dropped and must be retrieved, and dying before you retrieve it will mean you lost that gold. As an achievement collector, Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove scratches that itch, with achievements spread across all four campaigns including the versus-based mode, Showdown. Plenty of achievements are seriously tough, too, with ones that involve breaking every checkpoint in the game, not dying once in the entirety of the game, and beating the campaigns without ANY upgrades. That's no joke.

The graphics are gorgeous and the artists at Yacht Club Games have proven themselves as masters of pixel art. Every little sprite from the characters to the backgrounds are beautifully crafted in every way. I really love it. Music can't be understated either; I have it on Spotify and some of those songs are serious earworms.

Treasure Trove comes with FOUR campaigns each focused on different characters, and each character plays very differently. These four campaigns are Shovel of Hope, Plague of Shadows, Specter of Torment, and King of Cards. The fifth isn't really a campaign but more of a 2-player mode with a story mode attached.

The campaigns, ranked:

- SHOVEL OF HOPE -

While the subsequent campaigns are amazing on their own, Shovel of Hope still takes the cake for me thanks to the gameplay of Shovel Knight himself. He's easy to control, his gameplay is classic and fun, and it has the virtue of simply being the game that started it all. The story is engaging, the levels are extremely well-crafted, the bosses are awesome, and the campaign overall is just a masterpiece.

- KING OF CARDS -

King of Cards comes in second in the list of my favorite campaigns. At first I found King Knight very difficult to get the hang of, having to combine shoulder bashes with indirect aerial hits and a health bar that drained faster than I was used to. However, with more health, vigor, and heirlooms, I quickly began to enjoy playing him just as much, if not more than Shovel Knight at times.

What really stood out to me was the completely new set of zone maps filled with levels that were slightly shorter and didn't involve bosses at the end, as well as secret exits that opened up more paths on the map. Each map has its own boss, but what's great is that the random adventurers that would pop up to fight you in Shovel of Hope were the bosses from the original campaign.

Finally, a huge (albeit optional) part of King Knight's adventure is the Joustus card game that you're able to play. Although I wasn't interested in it, I didn't mind playing it given its necessity for 100% completion.

King of Cards is able to stand above Plague of Shadows and Specter of Torment because of its increased originality. It kind of feels like the Plague of Shadows variant of Specter of Torment, with similar levels but an overall more enjoyable experience.

- PLAGUE OF SHADOWS -

Between the two final knights, I found it easy to put Plague Knight's campaign above Specter Knight's because of Plague Knight's gameplay. Yes, he's very indirect and tricky to maneuver, but given the right bombs and arcana, you can really give yourself the advantage. This advantage is what made playing him so damn fun for me, and I really enjoyed playing an identical campaign as a character that fights from range. Switching up bombs on the fly for maximum effect is fun as hell, and Plague Knight's aesthetic is easily my favorite of the four. Story-wise, however, I wasn't as invested as Specter of Torment.

- SPECTER OF TORMENT -

I want to be clear here: I didn't dislike Specter of Torment. At all. On its own it's absolutely fantastic, and Specter Knight's gameplay and aesthetic is awesome. The campaign itself was great, and the fact that EVERY level was completely original similar to King of Cards made it a very solid campaign. I liked that it built much of the campaign around maneuvering Specter Knight through the levels rather than focusing on combat, giving it an interesting relationship toward platforming. Story-wise, I'd say it even ranks just below Shovel of Hope.

However... of the four campaigns, it's my least favorite. Don't get me wrong, Specter Knight's movement tricks were really cool, but his gameplay just wasn't as fun for me as the other's. The campaign was also just too easy, I think. I suppose to an extent I get that, though, as it came right after Plague of Shadows which is considered one of the harder characters to play. However, I enjoyed Plague Knight's gameplay from the get-go, so I actually found it to be kind of a step down when I compared. The Will Skull makes death a difficult thing to achieve.

The bosses were cool, as they always are, but they were also too damn easy. Specter of Torment feels like a power trip and it was fun as hell but it was the weakest campaign in comparison to me.

85093698.review:
Este jogo é maravilhoso, e é o melhor jogo retrô que já joguei.

É uma aula de game design, em que os elementos são apresentados gradualmente e sem perigo imediato antes dos desafios maiores aparecerem, de modo que quando você chega numa sala com umas 10 coisas diferentes acontecendo, você já sabe exatamente como cada uma delas funciona. O resultado é um jogo que quando você morre, você não pensa "que jogo sacana!", mas sim "ah, entendi... vou tentar de novo".

A história é simples e bobinha, mas com lampejos de profundidade e reviravoltas que a deixam muito agradável. É como se você estivesse entrando em um mundo que já tem uma história longa, e que por mais clichê que seja, ainda é muito satisfatória. O jogo é cheio de um humor leve, que transparece em detalhes sutis, diálogos breves, e animações. Estas animações, inclusive, são muito bem feitas. O jogo, apesar de (ou exatamente por ser) pixel-art, tem uma legibilidade fantástica, e a escolha de cores, mesmo com uma paleta limitada, é sempre feita em prol do jogador. Você nunca fica em dúvida sobre o que é plano de fundo e o que são elementos que você pode pisar ou interagir.

O jogo foi lançado em uma versão inicial, só com o Shovel Knight, e depois foi expandido pra incluir mais 3 personagens que estavam no jogo original. Pessoalmente, achei o segundo (Plague Knight) confuso e difícil de controlar, e o quarto (King Knight) um pouco simplista demais, e com uma mecânica de jogo de cartas que não me agradou muito. O terceiro cavaleiro, certamente, foi o que achei mais divertido, perdendo somente para o original. Os dois (Specter Knight e Shovel Knight) parecem muito com o Zero e o Megaman, em termos de estilo e controles (e esquema de cores, vermelho e azul).

Jogo fortemente recomendado pra qualquer pessoa remotamente interessada em jogos de plataforma. Ou pixel-art. Ou música de jogos. Ou jogos retrô.
